text.0: ADAM DAVY'S FIVE DREAMS ABOUT EDWARD II. [ Laud MS. 622 ( end of the 14 th cent. ), leaf 26, back. ] TO oure lorde Iesu crist in heuene, Ich to-day shewe myne sweuene, þat ich mette in one ni&yogh;th, Of a kni&yogh;th of mychel mi&yogh;th: His name is ihote sir Edward þe kyng, Prince of Wales Compare "Nou is Edward of Carnarvon King of Engelond al aplyht", in "The Elegy on the Death of Edw. I", from Harl. 2253, leaf 73, in Mr Thos. Wright's Political Songs , for the Camden Society, 1839, p. 249. Edw. III was never created Prince of Wales. The Black Prince was, but was never king. , Engelonde þe faire þing. Me mette þat he was armed wel, Boþe wiþ yrne & wiþ stel; And on his helme þat was of stel, A Coroune of gold bicom hym wel. Bifore the shryne of seint Edward he stood, Myd glad chere, & mylde of mood, Mid two kni&yogh;ttes armed on eiþer side, þat he ne mi&yogh;th þennes goo ne ride. hetilich A.S. hetelice , hatefully, hotly. hij leiden hym vpon, Als hij mi&yogh;tten myd swerd don. He stood þere wel swiþe stille, And þoled al-to-gedres her wille; No strook ne &yogh;af he a&yogh;einward To þilk þat hym weren wiþerward A.S. wiðer , against; wiðerweard , contrary, adverse. . Wounde ne was þere blody non, Of al þat hym þere was don. ¶ After þat me þou&yogh;th, onon, As þe tweie kni&yogh;ttes weren gon, In eiþer ere of oure kyng þere spronge out a wel fare þing: Hij wexen out so bri&yogh;th so glem þat shyneþ of þe sonne-bem; Of diuers coloures hij weren, þat comen out of boþe his eren ffoure bendes alle by rewe on eiþer ere, Of diuers colours, red & white als hij were; Als fer as me þou[&yogh;th] ich mi&yogh;th see, hij spredden fer & wyde in þe cuntre. fforsoþe me mette þis ilk sweuene— Ich take to witnesse god of heuene— þe wedenysday bifore þe decollacioun of seint Ion Decollation of John the Baptist, Aug. 29.—Nicolas. , It is more þan twelue moneþ gon. God me graunte so heuene blis, As me mette þis sweuene as it is. Now god þat is heuene kyng, To mychel ioye tourne þis metyng! A Noþer sweuene me mette, on a tiwes-ni&yogh;th Bifore the fest of alle halewen All Hallows, or All Saints' Day, Nov. 1.—Nicolas. , of þat ilk kni&yogh;th; His name is nempned here-bifore; Blissed be þe tyme þat he was bore! ffor we shullen þe day see, Emperour ychosen he worþe of cristiente. God vs graunte þat ilk bone, þat þilk tydyng here we sone Of sir Edward oure derworþ kyng Ich mette of hym anoþere fair metyng: To oure lorde of heuene ich telle þis, þat my sweuene tourne to mychel blis. Me þou&yogh;th he rood vpon an Asse— And þat ich take god to witnesse!— ywonden he was in a Mantel gray; Toward Rome he nom his way; Vpon his heuede sat an gray hure; It semed hym wel a mesure; he rood wiþouten hose & sho,— his wone was nou&yogh;th so forto do;— his shankes semeden al blood rede; Myne herte wop for grete drede; Als a pilgryme he rood to Rome, And þider he com wel swiþe sone. ÞE þrid sweuene me mette a ni&yogh;th, Ri&yogh;th of þat derworþe kni&yogh;th; þe wedenysday a ni&yogh;th it was, Next þe day of seint lucie 'Lucy. Virgin and Martyr, Dec. 13.'—Nicolas. bifore cristenmesse. Ich shewe þis, god of heuene: To mychel ioye he tourne my sweuene! Me þou&yogh;th þat ich was at Rome, And þider ich com swiþe sone: þe Pope 'pope' crosst through . , & sir Edward oure kyng, Boþe hij hadden a newe dubbyng; Hure gray was her cloþing; Of oþere cloþes sei&yogh; ich noþing. þe pope 'pope' crosst through . &yogh;ede bifore, mytred wel faire I-wys; þe kyng Edward com corouned myd gret blis; þat bitokneþ he shal be Emperour in cristianete: Iesus crist ful of grace, Graunte oure kyng, in euery place, Maistrie of his wiþerwynes A.S. wiðerwynna , adversary, enemy. , And of alle wicked sarasynes! Me met a sweuene, on worþing-ni&yogh;th I can't find what or when this is. . Of þat ilche derworþe kni&yogh;th; God ich it shewe, & to witnesse take, And so shilde me fro synne & sake! In-to an chapel ich com of oure lefdy; Iesus crist, hire leue son, stood by; On rode he was, an louelich Man, Als þilk þat on rode was don. He vnneiled his honden two, And seide, 'wiþ þe kni&yogh;th he wolde go': "Maiden, & moder, & mylde quene, Ich mote my kni&yogh;th to-day sene. Leue moder, &yogh;iue me leue, ffor ich ne may no lenger bileue; Ich mote conueye þat ilk kni&yogh;th, þat vs haþ serued day and ni&yogh;th: In pilerinage he wil gon, To bien awreke of oure fon." "Leue son, &yogh;oure wille, so mote it be, for þe kni&yogh;th boþe day & ni&yogh;th haþ serued me, Boþe at oure wille wel faire I-wys, þerfore he haþ serued heuene-riche blis." God þat is in heuene so bri&yogh;th, Be wiþ oure kyng boþe day & ni&yogh;th! Amen, Amen, so mote it be! þerto biddeþ a pater noster & an Aue. ¶ Adam, þe marchal, of stretford-atte-bowe— Wel swiþe wide his name is yknowe,— He hym-self mette þis metyng— To witnesse he takeþ Iesu heuene kyng,— On Wedenysday in clene leinte A voice me bede I ne shulde nou&yogh;th feinte; Of þe sweuenes þat her ben write, I shulde swiþe don my lorde kyng to wite. Ich ansuerde, 'þat I ne mi&yogh;th for derk gon.' þe vois me bad goo, for li&yogh;th ne shuld ich faile non, And þat I ne shulde lette for noþing, þat ich shulde shewe þe kyng my metyng. fforþ ich went swiþe onon, Estward as me þou&yogh;th ich mi&yogh;th gon: þe li&yogh;th of heuene me com to, As ich in my waye shulde go. "Lorde, my body ich &yogh;elde þee to, What &yogh;oure wille is wiþ me to do. Ich take to witnesse god of heuene, þat soþlich ich mette þis ilche sweuene "The Lady protests too much, methinks."— Hamlet , III. ii. 240. ! I ne reiche what &yogh;ee myd my body do, Als wisselich Iesus of heuene my soule vndergo." ÞE þursday next þe beryng of oure lefdy Nativity of the Virgin Mary, Sept. 8.—Nicolas. , Me þou&yogh;th an Aungel com sir Edward by: þe Aungel bitook sir Edward on honde; Al bledyng þe foure forþer clawes so were of þe lombe. At Caunterbiry, bifore þe hei&yogh;e autere, þe kyng stood, ycloþed al in rede: murre he was of þat blee red as blood. God, þat was on gode-friday don on þe rode, So turne my sweuene ni&yogh;th & day to mychel gode! Tweye poynt&yogh; þere ben þat ben vnshewed, ffor me ne worþe to clerk ne lewed; Bot to sir Edward oure kyng, hym wil ich shewe þilk metyng. ¶ Ich telle &yogh;ou forsoþe wiþouten les, Als god of heuene maide marie to moder ches, þe Aungel com to me, Adam Dauy, & sede, "Bot þou, Adam, shewe þis, þee worþe wel yuel mede!" þerfore, my lorde sir Edward þe kyng, I shewe &yogh;ou þis ilk metyng, As þe Aungel it shewed me in a visioun. Bot þis tokenyng bifalle, so dooþ me in-to prisoun! Lorde, my body is to &yogh;oure wille MS. willelle. ; þei&yogh; &yogh;ee willeþ me þerfore spille, Ich it wil take in þolemodenesse, Als god graunte vs heuene blisse; And lete vs neuere þerof mysse, þat we ne moten þider wende in clennesse! Amen, amen, so mote it be, And lete vs neuere to oþere waye tee! Who so wil speke myd me, Adam þe marchal, In stretforþe-bowe he is yknowe, & ouere al. Ich ne shewe nou&yogh;th þis forto haue mede, Bot for god almi&yogh;tties drede; ¶ ffor it is sooþ. [Follows, The Jest of Alisaunder , printed in Weber's Romances , vol. i. "DIuers is þis myddellerede To lewed Men & to lerede; Bysynesse / care & sorou&yogh; Is myd Man vche morow&yogh;e." (&c.)]

0.1: (1) ALle þat willen here in ryme Hou gode Men in olde tyme Loueden god almi&yogh;th, þat weren riche of grete valoure, Kynges sones and Emperoure, Of bodies stronge & li&yogh;th: &yogh;ee habbeþ yherd ofte in geste Of holy men maken feste Boþe daye & ni&yogh;th, fforto haue þe ioye in heuene wiþ Aungels song & mery steuene, þere blis is brode & bri&yogh;th.
0.2: (2) ¶ To &yogh;ou alle, hei&yogh;e & lowe, þe ri&yogh;th soþe to biknowe &yogh;oure soules forto saue, þe self waye þat god &yogh;ede To folowe hym I wolde &yogh;ou rede, heuene forto craue; And so duden þapostles alle, þat to Iesu wolden calle, ffor nou&yogh;th þai nolde bilaue, And to penaunce þai hem took, werldes wele þai al forsook Oure lordes loue to haue
0.3: (3) ¶ þise oþere holy seintz & gode, Martirs, virgines mylde of mode, And þise confessoures, Religious þat her lijf willen di&yogh;th, fforto seruen god almi&yogh;th By tides & by houres; &yogh;ee haue yherd saide wel ofte Man may nou&yogh;th lede lijf to softe, And wonen in heuene boures. þe godspel seiþ we moten lete werldes lijf, þat þinkeþ vs swete, And suffren hard shoures,
0.4: (4) ¶ ffader & moder & werldes goode, And folowe hym þat dyed on rode ffor oure synnes sake; And þan shullen we haue his loue, And ioye & blis wiþ hym a-boue þat he for vs gan make. I shal &yogh;ou now telle wiþ mouþe Of on þat is name couþe þat suffred woo & wrake. his holy lijf & his godenesse I may tellen more & lesse, In woo hou he gan wake.
0.5: (5) ¶ he forsook confort of al his kynde, Richesse he lete al bihynde, To god al he hym took: Alexius is his name in storie, writen of whom is made memorie In many holy book. In Rome, þat was noble Cite, woned a Man of grete pouste, þat mychel mirþe a [MS. of a] wook; his lijf he lad worschiplich, honoured he was of pouere & riche þat on hym gan look.
0.6: (6) ¶ Eufeniens was his name; Of godenesse was his fame In þe Cite of Rome. þerfore þe riche Emperoure Of þe Cite made hym Cenatoure. ffor loos of his wisdome. Riche he was of grete honoures, Of londes, Castels, & of toures; Men speken of hym ylome In alle þinges wiþouten strijf; Vche man he tau&yogh;tte holy lijf To his court þat come.
0.7: (7) ¶ Stronge he was in armes & li&yogh;th, A&yogh;eins Erle, baroun, & kni&yogh;th, his lordes ri&yogh;th to defende; þerfore hym loued þe Emperoure, And made hym maister & gouern|oure Of his tresore to spende. To his somouns in armes clers Two þousandes he had of bachelers, þat curteis weren & hende, And alle yshred in cloþes of golde, None fairer mi&yogh;tten ben on molde, In þe werldes ende.
0.8: (8) ¶ Men þat &yogh;eden in pilerinage And Men of ordre [MS. oydre] , was his vsage Often forto fede. Dame Agloes hi&yogh;th his spouse, Her dedes weren wel preciouse Holy lijf to lede. She was fair honeste & wijs, Louelich, & of gret prijs, Ycome of gode kynrede; A&yogh;eins no Man she mystook, wiþ contenaunce ne wiþ look, Noiþer in word ne dede.
0.9: (9) ¶ Barayne was þat gode wijf, In sorou&yogh; she ledde her lijf, ffor she no childe hadde. hir lorde for þat ilk þinge Ofte his honden gan to wrynge, And sorou&yogh;ful lijf he ladde; ffor he wende þat god almi&yogh;th had ben wrooþ wiþ hym apli&yogh;th, þereof sore hym dradde. Ofte he bisou&yogh;th god in heuene Sende hem a childe, wiþ mylde steuene, To maken hem bliþe & gladde,
0.10: (10) ¶ Conforte of hym forto haue, her godes after hem to saue, her londes & her ledes; her eyre of hym forto make, And her richesse hym bitake, Palfreies & her stedes. Ofte þai maden þus her bone, And god sent hem grace sone, þat fulfilde were þoo dedes: A son conceyued þat gode wijf; Tyme com in her olde lijf ybore it most be nedes
0.11: (11) ¶ þai þankeden god, & glade were, And avoweden in þis manere Chastite boþe to take, And to lyuen in clene lijf, Eufeniens & his gode wijf, And synne to forsake. þe childe was mery in al manere, As þai maden her praiere, Ani&yogh;th as þai gan wake. Alexius þai gonnen hym calle; yloued he was amonges hem alle þat to hym gonnen take.
0.12: (12) ¶ Alexius was sett to boke, To gode maistres þai hym toke, And wise of clergie. þe more he wex in elde & lengþe, To seruen god he dude his strengþe And his moder Marie. To þe Emperour whan he was brou&yogh;th þere dedes of Armes weren ywrou&yogh;th To lernen chiualrye; þere mi&yogh;th he sen in tour[na]ment what kni&yogh;th was dou&yogh;ttiest of dent And man of most maistrie.
0.13: (13) ¶ His fader was boþe wijs & ware, ffor þat his son so wel hym bare, he loued hym al his lijf. he þou&yogh;th to don swiche puruyaunce, whar-wiþ he mi&yogh;th hym avaunce And wynne hym a wijf. To a riche prince his son he sent, And afterward to hym he went, Stille wiþouten strijf: A dou&yogh;tter he had, bri&yogh;th & shene, þe heritage shulde hires bene Of Castel & londes rijf.
0.14: (14) ¶ whan ayþer herd oþeres wille, And speken þerof to-gedre stille To make þat sposaile, Of þe tyme comen was þe day To fulfille wiþouten delay, Certeyn, wiþouten faile, To þe chirche of seint Bonefas wiþ þis maiden þai token þe pas, þat hei&yogh;e was of paraile; As custume was & shulde be, þai maden gret solempnite, þe Pope & his conseile.
0.15: (15) ¶ Alexius was shamefast, And of weddyng he was agast, his vijs al pale bywent; Leuer hym were to be ded þan haue ytrowed þat ilk red By his owen assent. He ne wist what he mi&yogh;th don; fful gret sorou&yogh; com hym on, he helde hym-self shent. To god he gan hym al affye, And to his moder seint Marie, Trewely, wiþ gode entent.
0.16: (16) ¶ Naþeles he lete his heuynysse, And made mychel ioye & blisse At þat solempnite. He bare hym curteislich & tsllie, To fulfille his faders wille, Glad as he had ybe. ffulfild was þe weddyng wiþ ioye & blis in al þing, þat many man mi&yogh;th see. þe ni&yogh;th was comen, & þe day gon, þe kni&yogh;ttes waten on & on To her owen cuntre.
0.17: (17) ¶ Eufeniens his son gan calle, And tidynges amonge hem alle He tolde hym þat were newe. 'Son, to þi chaumbre þou most wende, To þi wijf fair & hende, Blysful & bri&yogh;th of hewe.' And whan Alixius herd þat word It pricked his hert as speres oord, So sore it gan hym rewe; Bot his fader wraþþi he nolde, He had leuer be vnder molde, þat neuer man hym knewe.
0.18: (18) ¶ whan þe folk was went away, And he al-one in chaumbre lay, Alexius gan to preche; Of Iesu he bigan his game, werldes likyng he gan blame, his &yogh;onge wijf to teche. He tau&yogh;tte hir, þat was so hende, Hou she shulde haue god to frende þat is oure soules leche; &yogh;if she wolde alle her lijf Duelle boþe maiden & wijf, þe fende she mi&yogh;th do wreche.
0.19: (19) ¶ þat maiden herkned swiþe stille, And whan he seide had al his wille þe holy gost hir lau&yogh;tte, And she hym graunted wiþ mylde mood To louen Iesu þat dyed [on] rood, As he hym-self hir tau&yogh;tte. Alexius was þoo glad & bliþe, his ioye couþe he noman kiþe; his spouse a ryng he rau&yogh;tte, And seide to hir, 'my suete þing, Take to þee þis ilk ryng, And kepe it in þine au&yogh;tte.
0.20: (20) ¶ 'Of me whan þou wilt haue mynde Loke here-on, as þou art hende, Boþe by day & ni&yogh;th. In pilerynage now wil I go, And half þe godenesse þat I do Graunte þee god almi&yogh;th.' Alexius þus his leue tooke; Rewely his wijf gan on hym loke þat was so fair & [MS. w] bri&yogh;th; She ne wist to what londe þat she mi&yogh;th sende hym any sonde, Doune fel þat swete wi&yogh;th.
0.21: (21) ¶ Alixius from his richesse In-to pouert & wrecchednesse, ffrom his frendes he fledde. vnto þe Cee he com wel sory, A shippe he fonde to seil redy, þe holy gost hym ledde. Of his golde & of his pens wel he aquited his despens, hendely of þat he hedde. þe wynde aroos at her wille, wheþer þai wolde, loude or stille; At her likyng þai spedde.
0.22: (22) ¶ At a Cite Galys men calle To londe þai gonnen aryuen alle, wiþouten enpeirement. Alexius of hem took leue, And worschiplich þai hym &yogh;eue: To chircheward he went. He þanked god wiþ good wille Erly & late, loude & stille, þat þider hem hadde sent. He bisou&yogh;th god, & gan to wepe, þat from þe fende he shulde hym kepe And his enticement.
0.23: (23) ¶ þus he þat had riche wedes, Hei&yogh;e hors, & gode stedes, And Armes bri&yogh;th & shene, Al he leet þe godes gret, And went on his bare feet, his soule to make clene. Ofte it fel in his mende Of his fader & moder hende, þat sou&yogh;th he schulde bene. He wolde for none kynnes þing þat Men hadden of hym knouyng, þerfore he gan to flene.
0.24: (24) ¶ ffrom þat cuntre swiþe he &yogh;ede, To-ward Surrie in feble wede, þat noman shulde hym knowe. þere he duelled in grete pouerte, In hunger, in þorst, & oþer smerte, þat many man it sowe. þe Cee of grece passed he is, In-to þe Cite of Annys, He com þat ilk þrowe. God he bitau&yogh;tte his compaignye, And &yogh;ede to a chirche of seint Marie wiþ herte meke and lowe.
0.25: (25) ¶ At þat chirche is an ymage Of oure lefdy vpon a stage, þat many man haþ sou&yogh;th. It was ymaked of Aungels honde, To def & doumbe of oþere londe Miracle þere was wrou&yogh;th. Alexius was glad & bliþe, His ioye couþe he noman kiþe, In hert ne in þou&yogh;th, whan he mi&yogh;th seen in signe Hou goddes ymage fair & digne In his moders barme was brou&yogh;th.
0.26: (26) ¶ Often he made his orisoune, wepande wiþ deuocioune, To þe quene of heuene, And seide, 'moder mylde & free, Praie þi son of gret pouste ffor his names seuene, þat from heuene com to þee, By assent of þe trinite, þorou&yogh; þe Aungels steuene, Here to suffre many peynes In al his body & his veynes, In erþe as I can neuene,
0.27: (27) ¶ 'And þat he sheweþ in his mercy, Marie, to þee I make my cry, þat am a synful Man; ffor wiþ his blood & peynes grene, þe whiche to vs purchaced ene, ffro helle he vs wan. Swete Iesu, heuene sire, warisshed he is þat wil þe desire ffrom þe fende sathan. wel is hym þat suffren may ffor þi loue ni&yogh;th oiþere day, Peyne þat paie þee can.'
0.28: (28) ¶ whan noþing nas hym bileued, And he fer from his frendes to dreued, his cloþes weren to rent. Amonge þe pouere in þe chirche haw&yogh;e he begged, & was her felaw&yogh;e, And took þat god hym sent. Almesse þat god hym &yogh;eue, þe pouer þat wolde þere bileue wiþ hym in present, He &yogh;af þat haluendel & more, And was hym-self of hungred sore, And took it in good entent.
0.29: (29) ¶ Euery sonenday houseled he was, And shryuen also of vche trespas þat fel to any synne. Michel he waked & litel he sleep, Of þat he shulde his body wiþ kepe, Litel hym com wiþinne. ffrom þe tyme he took his tourne ffrom Rome, þere he was borne, he was sou&yogh;th of his kynne In alle cuntrees, in euery toun, In chirche, in felde, vp & doun, ffor nou&yogh;th wolde þai blynne.
0.30: (30) ¶ His kynrede com þere hym biside, þat had ysou&yogh;th hym fer & wide, & &yogh;af hym her Almesse, As he sat amonge þe pouere, In grete meschief & stronge to couere, ffor hunger in wrecchednesse. Sore of hym þai gonnen rewe, Stille he satt, & wel hem knewe, Her names more & lesse. Ychaunged was his faire hewe þorou&yogh; reyn & wynde þat on hym blewe, And oþer stronge destresse.
0.31: (31) ¶ whan þai mi&yogh;tten nou&yogh;th spede, Ne hym of axen in no þede Ne in no londe of take, wiþ sorou&yogh; þai gradde, allas! allas! And wenten to Rome, þe ri&yogh;th pas, her sorou&yogh; mi&yogh;th nou&yogh;th slake. Alexius noþing þou&yogh;th, Bot on Iesu crist he þou&yogh;th, And grete ioye he gan make ffor he ne was nou&yogh;th biknowe Of his frendes hei&yogh;e ne lowe, His welþe gan a-wake.
0.32: (32) ¶ Eufeniens seide in his mende, 'þe most wrecche fer oiþere hende Certes now am I. Conforte ne ioye ne may me come; Now my childe is me bynome My song is tourned to cry. My wijf is barayne, & ek olde; She ne may haue no childe for colde, Oure heir al forto by. In sorou&yogh; & care my lijf is di&yogh;th, ffor to dye it were my ri&yogh;th, And hennes to party.'
0.33: (33) ¶ wiþ þat his moder fel to grounde And lay yswowen a longe stounde, And roos vp al afrayed: 'My leue son, þat were so meke, I ne woot where I shal þee seke, þerefore I am dismayed.' His moder ne mi&yogh;th lete sorou&yogh;, Neiþer at euene ne at morowe, In saw&yogh;e as it is seide. To hir chaumbre she went in hast, And of hire bedd þe cloþes doun cast, And siþen hem al to breyde,—
0.34: (34) ¶ Ciclatounes þat weren of prijs, Pelured wiþ Ermyne & wiþ grijs, Alle she cast away, And wered cloþes symple & blake. Litel she sleep, & mychel gan wake, And fasted euery daye. 'Lorde,' she seide, 'almi&yogh;tty, To þee & to þi moder mary I make a vow, & saye, þat I shal neuer hennes wende Tyl Alexius come oiþer sende, Oiþer I be roted in clay.'
0.35: (35) ¶ Now mowen &yogh;ee here pleynt pitouse Of Alexius trewe spouse, Hou she made her mone; In gret sorou&yogh; was hir entent, Her here she drou&yogh;, her cloþes rent, Grymly she gan grone. 'Al my &yogh;ouþe & my solas, Myne hope, is lorne, allas, And my bidyng alone. I. am boþe maiden & wijf, I. noot to whom telle my strijf, I lyue as ankre in stone.
0.36: (36) ¶ 'Siþþe I ne haue to whom me mene, Lijk is my lijf on to sene— þat am wiþouten red— þe turtel þat is for sorou&yogh; lene, And tredeþ on no gras grene, Siþen hire make is ded. Allas, hou shal I. ioye haue? Oiþer hou shal I my-seluen saue To lyue in maidenhede? Me were leuer of hym a si&yogh;th, þan welde al þis londe ri&yogh;th In lengþe & in brede.'
0.37: (37) ¶ She roos vp erlich a morowe, And to his moder she went in sorou&yogh; ffor loue of hire spouse, And praied hir þat she most duelle wiþ hir, þat sorou&yogh;ful pleynt to telle, þat strong was and greuouse. þe lefdy was wel apaied whan she had þus yseied, þat was so preciouse. And at oo bed & oo cloþing, Seuentene &yogh;er was her duellyng Boþe in one house.
0.38: (38) ¶ Lordynges, &yogh;ee þat willeþ lere, a faire miracle &yogh;ee mowen here: Bifore þat self ymage, þere þat Alexius sate wiþ pouere men in þe gate As a pouere page, þe ymage, þat aungels gonne wirche, Spaak to þe serieauntz of þe chirche þere she stood on þe stage, And hete hem alle wiþouten lettynge Goddes sergeaunt to chirche brynge wiþouten any outrage.
0.39: (39) ¶ 'He is ri&yogh;th stedfast of lijf; His werkes shullen ben made rijf Ouer al fer & neere. þe holy gost wiþinne hym rest; Charite sitteþ in his breest, Brennande as fyre. Longe in pouerte his lijf he haþ led; He ne com neuere in no bed þise seuentene &yogh;ere; His holy lijf, bot god alone, Ne woot non in þis werldes wone; To seint&yogh; he may be pere.'
0.40: (40) ¶ þe sergeauntz lepen out in hast, As men þat weren sore agast, And ful of grete drede Of þe ymage þat to hem spak Of goddes sergeaunt wiþouten lak þat sat in beggers wede. wyde aboute þai hym sou&yogh;th, And &yogh;ut founden þai hym nou&yogh;th Amonge þe pouere felawrede; And whan þai nou&yogh;th hym fynde mi&yogh;th, To þat ymage onon ri&yogh;th Hastilich þai &yogh;ede,
0.41: (41) ¶ To þat Maryole wiþ teres clere, And bisou&yogh;th hir on þis manere, 'þat she sent hem grace Goddes man hou þai shulden knowe, þat had ben hei&yogh;e & bare hym lowe, And where he sat in place.' þe ymage spaak ofte wordes newe, 'I &yogh;ou hote, sergeaunt&yogh; trewe, A&yogh;ein[ward] þat &yogh;ee pace; Amonge þe pouere he sitteþ, to-tore Boþe bihynde & bifore, wiþ a lene face.'
0.42: (42) ¶ þe sergeaunt&yogh; stirten out skeet, þai founden hym, & kisten his feet, And mercy þai hym cryde, And ledden hym in-to holy chirche, Goddes werkes forto wirche, þereinne to abide. Of þe gode mannes loos þe miracle & þe cry aroos Ouere al in vche syde; Michel poeple þider ran, Of þe miracles þat herden þan, Of cuntrees fer & wyde;
0.43: (43) ¶ And worschiped hym in word & dede, Alle þat mi&yogh;tten in lengþe & brede; And duden hym gret honoure, And beden hym, boþe day & ni&yogh;th, He bere her erande to god almi&yogh;th þat is oure saueoure. þo was Alexius swiþe woo ffor þat he was honoured soo, And made grete doloure; For swiche honoure & swiche glorie, As it is writen in his storye, He ne loued in toun ne toure.
0.44: (44) ¶ ffor þat his meryte wolde slake þat he shulde of god take, þerfore it liked hym ille. werldes honoure forto flee, Al by ni&yogh;th, in pryuete, He stale away ful stille In-to þe londe of Galys. To seint Iames chirche I-wys he com wiþ gode wille, And þere he sete amonge pouere men, And beged his mete in þe fen, his penaunce to fulfille.
0.45: (45) ¶ þoo he had þere twelfmonþe ysete wiþ pouere Men, & begged his mete, His fadres sergeaunt&yogh; come And sou&yogh;tten hym forsoþe I-wys In pilerynage at Galys, To bryngen hym to Rome. And whan Alexius hem gan see, Stillelich he gan flee, As man of ri&yogh;t wisdome: In-to thars he þou&yogh;th fare, And at þe Royn he fonde &yogh;are A shippe þat was al tome,
0.46: (46) ¶ And Pilgrymes gret plente þat wolden passen ouer þe Cee, To tars þat wolden &yogh;are. He bad þe shipman, for goddes loue þat is in heuene vs aboue, he most wiþ hem fare. Grete grucchyng þai alle made; Alexius fer & ner gan wade, ffor nou&yogh;th wolde he spare; Euere he cried loude & shille, Til þai graunted hym his wille, þoo was he out of care.
0.47: (47) ¶ þai drowen vp seil, þe wynde was good, And saileden ouer þe salt flood, þe weder was at her wille; vntil, þe þrid dayes ende, Swiche a storme Iesus gan sende, þat alle hem liked ille. þai wenden wel haue went to tars; þe wynde was gret, & noþing skars, þonder dyned shille; ffor li&yogh;ttynges grete, & þonder blast, wel sore þe poeple was agast, þai grete & groned grille.
0.48: (48) ¶ þe wynde hem droof, forsoþe to seyne, In-to þe londe of Romeyne, þere Alexius was borne; þoo was þe poeple in wel more care, ffor þat þai were aryued þare, þan þai weren er biforne; ffor þat tyme were þe folk of Rome þe mest shrewen of cristendome wiþouten oþes ysworne. ffor pilgrymes þat aryueden þere, her catel þat þai wiþ hem bere, On hast was forlorne.
0.49: (49) ¶ Ri&yogh;th so bifel by þoo dawes By Alexius & his felawes. Of sorou&yogh; was her speche; Also sumtyme bifel a cas, þoo god almi&yogh;tty bad Ionas To Nyniue gon & preche; Ionas wist wel her wille, þe folk of niniue weren ille And wicked for to teche; Away Ionas wolde haue ystole ffrom goddes hest, & han hym hole; Ak sone hym fel a wreche.
0.50: (50) ¶ Ionas wende god bigile, And wolde haue went to anoþer yle In þe grikkissh Cee; he gan to shippen atte Ryuage; wynde aroos wiþ wood rage, þat sorou&yogh; it was to see. ffyue dayes euere iliche it lest wiþ sorou&yogh; & care, her tempest, þat seyl ne mi&yogh;th þere be. þan seide þe maister 'forsoþe Iwys Sum cursed Man amonges vs is, þat wel witen mowe we.
0.51: (51) ¶ 'we willeþ caste amonges vs alle, Lott, on whom it may bifalle, And ouere bord he shal be cast.' And whan þe prophete herde þis, He þou&yogh;th he had ydon amys, And was sore agast. þries þai beren aboute þat lot, Ac on Ionas fel vche grot, þe first and þe last. þe maister hym þrew ouere bord; A whal hym swalewe at oo word ffor oo morsel in hast;
0.52: (52) ¶ And þere he dwelled forsoþe apli&yogh;th þre dayes fulle & þre ni&yogh;th, ffor Ionas was vntrewe; And at þe þre dayes ende, Swiche grace god gan sende, þe Cee to londe hym þrewe. whan þe whal was comen to londe, þerto was many mannes honde On hym forto hewe; And whan þe whal was to-cleued, Ionas pylte vp his heued, And gan his body shewe.
0.53: (53) ¶ vp he roos, þe folk to teche, And goddes wordes he gan preche, And lered hem her lefnesse, And made hem wynne goddes loue, To wonen wiþ hym in heuene aboue, þe poeple more and lesse. ¶ Ri&yogh;th so Alexius had yment To Tars forto haue ywent; Ac god hym sent destresse, And made hym to Rome wende, To wonen þere among his frende, holy wryt bereþ witnesse.
0.54: (54) ¶ whan Alexius was to londe ygon, Seyl þai drou&yogh;en vp onon, And wenten in þe Cee, Al to thars till þai come ffro þe wicked londe of Rome, And maden solempnite. Alexius com in-to his owe, And of his frendes was he nou&yogh;th knowe, ffor so naked was he; And als a straunge man he went To his fader wiþ gode entent, And seide to hym par charite,
0.55: (55) ¶ 'Eufeniens, goddes frende, þou art holden good & hende, Alesed of gret Almesse! ffor his loue þat was ybete, And for vs suffred woundes grete, helpe me in þis destresse, ffor I ne can to no Man gon Mete to crauen, bot þee on, No herberewe more ne lesse; Make of me þi bede-man! And by hym þat þis werlde wan, þou mi&yogh;th haue heuene blis;
0.56: (56) ¶ '&yogh;iue me þe crommes of þi table,— þan doostou dedes merciable,— And herberewe in þine house; And of Alexius, þi son so fre, Afterward I shal telle þee, þat þou helde preciouse: þan shaltou be day & ni&yogh;th Glad, whan þou hym seest wiþ si&yogh;th, And ek þi trewe spouse.' Eufeniens ansuered þoo, 'I graunt wel þat it be so. þine bedes &yogh;if þou wilt ouse.'
0.57: (57) ¶ To a Man he hym bitook, þat seke Men couþe wel look, Nou&yogh;th as a Man of task; To kepe þat Man he bad hym þink, And brynge hym boþe mete & drynk whan he wolde ask. '&yogh;if god wil, my creatoure, He shal be kepte wiþ honoure, His peynes forto lask, To seien his bedes, & bidde for me To veray god in trinite, fforto he be roted to ask.'
0.58: (58) ¶ Eufeniens bad he shulde be þere þat he mi&yogh;th hym ysee late and erly; In þe halle he shulde be layd. was þere non þat it wiþsayd, Bot graunted hastyly; þai loued hym more þan any man. To kepe hym wel, he hete hem þan, And wisten neuer why His wijf hym loued at herte dere; wel wolde she þat he serued were, And mychel was hym by.
0.59: (59) ¶ wiþouten any grucchyng word, Mete þat was vpon hire bord þai senten hym to almesse, Ri&yogh;th of her owen dissh, were it flessh oiþer fissh, while he was in destresse; þus was þe pilegryme yserued þan. who he was, wist noman, Gret was his þolemodenesse; ffor &yogh;if his moder oiþer his wijf hadden ywist Alexius lijf, It had ben her gladnesse.
0.60: (60) ¶ wiþ hym þai speken, & hym sei&yogh;en wiþ her mouþe & wiþ her ei&yogh;en, ffader & moder & wijf; Nou&yogh;th for þan non hym knew, Noiþer by hide ne by hew; Al chaunged was his lijf. His fader he sei&yogh; often grete, And his moder teres lete ffourty siþes & fyue. yuel mi&yogh;th hym liken þat sei&yogh; þis; his martirdom was strong I-wys, Of sorou&yogh; & paynes ryue.
0.61: (61) ¶ Alexius in al wise Dude to god his seruise wiþ stedfast wille in hert, In fastyng, & in orisouns, In many manere deuociouns Of peynes þat weren smert. And al was forto wynne heuene; To here Aungels wiþ mylde steuene, he suffred þis pouert ffulle seuentene &yogh;er; he wered breech maked of her, And al swiche was his shert.
0.62: (62) ¶ Sergeauntz, þat þere-inne were, Ofte siþes gramed hym þere, And despised hym fast. þe wasshyng of her vessel þai cast on hym euerydel, þat was swiþe vnwrast; And cleped hym shrewe ypo|crite, And ofte-tymes gonne hym smyte Vnder þe cheke in hast: Ac Alexius was of god fulfild, In gode penaunce he it helde, And þanked hem at þe last.
0.63: (63) ¶ Alexius, þat was goddes kni&yogh;th, ffor penaunce þat was on hym li&yogh;th, Almest his lijf was lorne. Wel he sei&yogh;, þorou&yogh; deþes law&yogh;es, þat he drou&yogh; to his endyng daw&yogh;es, ffor deþ com hym biforne. His sergeaunt he cleped sone, And for his loue, bad hym a bone, þat bare þe crovne of þorne, To fecche hym enk & parchemyne, fforto write in latyne His lijf siþþe he was borne.
0.64: (64) ¶ His sergeaunt was glad & bliþe; Enk & parchemyn also swiþe He fette, & hym bitook; Alexius þo write bigan; Ak þere was non bifore þan þat wist he couþe in book. þere-inne he wroot oord & ende, Hou he fro his wijf gan wende, And al his kyn forsook; And hou Alex at his partyng, whan he took his wijf þe ryng, hou rewly she gan look;
0.65: (65) ¶ And hou in pilerynage he &yogh;ede, In hunger, in þorst, in pouere wede, And in what manere, And hou he sat in grete destresse Amonge þe pouere, & fenge almesse Seuentene &yogh;ere; And hou his frendes comen hym by, And he hem knew apertely, þat sou&yogh;tten hym fer & nere; And hou he stale a-way hem fro, þat non hym knew of alle þo, So chaunged was his chere;
0.66: (66) ¶ And hou þe ymage of oure lefdy þe sergeauntz hete apertely, In, hym, forto take, And byd his bedes in þe chirche, Goddes werkes þere to wirche, His sorou&yogh; forto slake; And hou þat folk com fer & wyde To þat chirche in vche syde, honour hym forto make; And hou he stale away hem fro, And wolde nou&yogh;th be honoured so, bot libbe in woo & wrake;
0.67: (67) ¶ And hou he wolde to tars haue went, And whiche a tempest god hym sent, þat droof hem to Romeyne; And hou he bad his fader good herberewe & oþer lyues food, He wroot forsoþe to seyne; And hou he sei&yogh; seuentene &yogh;ere ffader, & moder, & wijf þere, wiþ sorou&yogh; & mychel peyne; And he wolde hem nou&yogh;th yknowe, Bot bare hym boþe symple & lowe, þat had ben Man of meyne.
0.68: (68) ¶ Iesus, þat is kyng of glorie, his martirdom & his victorie Sei&yogh;, & his trauaile; And whan he had his lijf ywrite, he hidde þere noman shulde ywite, his book of gode paraile. Priuelich Alex it bare, þat noman mi&yogh;th þerof be-ware Hou mychel it wolde auaile; And, whan he dyed, I vnderstonde It was founden in his ri&yogh;th honde, writen wiþouten faile.
0.69: (69) ¶ On palme sonenday, after messe, In þe chirche amonge þe presse, A voice com, I &yogh;ou rede, ffrom heuene adoune, wel shille & clere, þat seide to hem in þis manere, where-of many gonne drede, And seide, '&yogh;ee þat trauailed be In hunger & þurst for loue of me, Comeþ! I shal &yogh;ou fede, In heuene, þat is so fair & bri&yogh;th, þare euere is day & neuere ni&yogh;th, And ioye wiþouten drede.'
0.70: (70) ¶ þe poeple & þe clergie, ffor þat voice songen þe letanye wiþ gode deuocioun; And bisou&yogh;tten þe heuene kyng, þat he shulde &yogh;iue hem tokenyng ffro heuene to erþe adoun, Of þe voice what it were þat among hem com þere wiþ so mery soun. þe voice com eft anoþer tyme, And seide as I schal seie in Ryme; Herkneþ þis resoun:
0.71: (71) ¶ 'þere is a Man of dedes gode, Spirituel, & mylde of mode, Now in Rome Cite; In penaunce he is &yogh;ou amonge, Certeynly &yogh;ee ne shullen nou&yogh;th longe here in erþe hym see; A gode fridayes morowenyng he shal wende to heuene kyng, þat sytteþ in trinite. Takeþ wiþ hym þe ri&yogh;th pace To þe chirche of seint Boneface wiþ grete solempnite.'
0.72: (72) ¶ þai sou&yogh;tten hym & nou&yogh;th ne founde, And hadden many sorou&yogh;ful stounde, Til þe gode fryday; wiþ gret deuocioun among, Of bedes & of chirche song, To god þai maden her pray; þai praiden hym for his pyte, And for his mychel humilite, þat he hem sent to say where was þe Man þe Aungel of tolde Twyes er þan wiþ wordes bolde, þat in swiche payne lay.
0.73: (73) ¶ þe þrid tyme com þe voice ffro hym þat was don on croice wiþ gret solempne li&yogh;th, And seide, 'wendeþ wiþoute soioure To Eufeniens þe Cenatoure, ffor þere he lijþ vche ni&yogh;th. Swiþe good haþ ben his lijf; His werkes shullen be made rijf; His soule is fair & bri&yogh;th.' þat ilk tyme, as I &yogh;ou seie, His gost went þe ri&yogh;th weie ffro þe body to god almi&yogh;th.
0.74: (74) ¶ þe holy pope Innocent And þe Emperoures swiþe went, Sire Eufeniens to calle, And chalenged hym in þis manere, Eufeniens & his wijf yfere, Ri&yogh;th amonge hem alle; 'In þine house is, þat is so meke, Goddes man þat we seke; Hou may þis cas bifalle? we haue ysou&yogh;th hym fer & wyde, Hou darstou goddes sergeaunt hyde In boure oiþer in halle?'
0.75: (75) ¶ Eufeniens ansuered sone, As he au&yogh;tte forto done, To þe pope Innocent, And seide, þei&yogh; he shulde deye, Of swiche a Man couþe he nou&yogh;th seye, By god omnipotent [MS. omnipototent] ; 'ffor swiche a Man &yogh;if I knewe, ffayn I wolde hym to &yogh;ou shewe Treuly wiþ god entent.' þan seiden þe Cardinales twelue, 'God &yogh;eue þat it were þi-selue Byfore vs in present.'
0.76: (76) ¶ In þat tyme tweie emperoures Of Rome kepten þe honoures wiþ her cristen menee; þat on hete Archadius, And þat oþere Honorius; þai weren hende & fre. wiþ Eufeniens þai wenten ri&yogh;th fforto fecchen goddes kni&yogh;th, þat was so good of fe. Ac eufeniens was swiþe li&yogh;th, And went bifore his hous to di&yogh;th wiþ gret solempnite
0.77: (77) ¶ Eufeniens, whan he hom cam, Al his meignee he vndernam, &yogh;if þat þai euere ysowe Any Man þat so holy were As þe Aungel tolde of ere, Of his meignee to knowe. Alexius wardeyn com þan, And seide, 'sir, it is &yogh;oure bede|man, þat lijþ ded by þe wowe; He þat þou hast so longe yfed, wiþ mete & drynk, clooþ &. bed, He bare hym euer lowe.
0.78: (78) ¶ 'I trowe wel it may so be, whom so &yogh;ee seche, þat it is he, ffor he was good of lijf; His bedes he bad as a frere, Ne wolde he nou&yogh;th, while he was here, Louen fi&yogh;th ne strijf; A book in his honde he halt Swiþe fast, & narewe yfalt, who þat it couþe descryue; I ne woot what he þereinne wrou&yogh;th; þe parchemyn I hym bou&yogh;th, Gon fourty dayes & fyue.'
0.79: (79) ¶ þoo þat þis herden þe Emperoures And oþere lordes of honoures, þai þankeden god almi&yogh;th. He led hem þere lay þat body, Clene & fair, & sumdel rody, fface feir & bri&yogh;th. þe on Emperoure his honde vp took, And wolde haue taken out þe book þat was fair of si&yogh;th; Alexius þe book helde þoo; þan was þe Emperour swiþe woo, And in his herte afli&yogh;th.
0.80: (80) ¶ þe Emperour þoo speke bigan, And seide vnto þe body þan, þere it lay in þe herne; 'þou&yogh; we ben Men of synful lijf, Emperours we ben wiþouten strijf, Rome forto gouerne; we defenden holy chirche A&yogh;eins hem þat wolden wirche Dedes stoute & sterne; þerfore delyuer vs þi book, þat þe poeple þere-on mowe look, wisdom forto lerne.'
0.81: (81) ¶ whan þai hadden so yseide, Alexius, þere he was yleide, Opened vp his honde; To þe pope wolde he nou&yogh;th forsake, Bot lete hym þoo þe book vptake, To rede þat he fonde. þoo þapostoile had his book, His chaunceler he it bitook To rede, I vnderstonde; Othoo was his name, A Man yholde of gode fame Ouer al Rome londe.
0.82: (82) ¶ þe book he red wiþ gode wille, þe folk herkned & helde hem stille wiþouten any boost Til þe book was red & seide. Alexius was bifore hem leide, ffulfild of þe holy gost. þe chaunceler wel loude grad whan he þe book of Alexius rad Among þe cristen ost; hou he fro frendes gan wende, And hou his fader fer & hende Sou&yogh;th hym by euery cost;
0.83: (83) ¶ And hou he was to þe Emperoure ysent, to be Man of valoure And lernen chiualrie, Of huntyng, & of Ryuere, Of chesse pleieyng & of tablere: Al nas worþ a flye; Leuer hym was to conne good, And seruen god wiþ mylde mood, and his moder Marie: And hou he &yogh;ede seuentene &yogh;er In pilerinage fer & ner wiþ mychel maladye;
0.84: (84) ¶ And oþer &yogh;eres seuentene wiþ his fader he had ybene, his bedeman by þe wowe, þat fader ne moder ne his wijf wisten of his holy lijf, Ne þat he was hire owe; And hou his fader sergeauntz alle, veyn glorie gonne hym calle, And gorre on hym gonne þrowe; And hou he þe book ywriten hadde: Of al his lijf, þere he it radde To þe poeple hei&yogh;e & lowe.
0.85: (85) ¶ þoo Eufeniens þise wordes herd, Of his son hou it ferd, Gret was his sorou&yogh;eyng; His face he [MS. his] rent, & his her. Men sorou&yogh;ed for hym fer & ner, He fel in swowenyng. On his owen son þat was, His cry was euere, 'allas! allas! deþ! why nyltou me stynge? Allas! sorou&yogh;! what is þi red? þou hast me brou&yogh;th vnto my ded; Myne herte wil to-sprynge.
0.86: (86) ¶ 'Now I may no ioye haue; No confort ne may me saue; My blis is al forlorne! ffor my son þat lijþ here ded, In elde he shulde haue ben my red. Allas! þat I was borne! O son, whi woldestou suffren smert, And dye wiþ me here in pouert, A begger as þou worne? To þi comyng was al my speire, To haue ymade of þee myne eire, Of londe, Castel & corne.'
0.87: (87) ¶ His moder herd þat tydynge; ffor hir son she gan flynge In Rage as a lyonesse; Sorou&yogh;-fullich her pleynt she made; Noman mi&yogh;th hire herte glade, Of al þe grete presse. His fader had ylore þe speche; To his moder was no leche þat mi&yogh;th her cry acesse. Letted she nou&yogh;th for al þe þrong, þat she ne ran þe poeple among, Hire son to clyppe & kysse.
0.88: (88) ¶ "O son, þat soke of myne pappes, þou hast ysent me sory happes, þus sone art went me fro. I wende haue yhad of þee solas; Myne hope is tynt, allas! allas! And welþe is went to woo. Son, þou doest vs stronge tourment! Oure ioye is al away went! ffor sorou&yogh; we shullen vs sle; ffor often þou sei&yogh; þi fader & me Erlich & late wepe for þee, And ek þi wijf also.
0.89: (89) ¶ 'þo þat þee shulden haue serued trewe, ffele tymes on þee þai þrewe ffilþe & foule vryne, And beten þee ofte swiþe sore; And þou suffredest euermore, And took it nou&yogh;th to pyne. Why woldestou cast þee in care, Of hem to suffre swiche bysmare, þat weren þine owen hyne? Of alle þise seuentene &yogh;ere Ne woldestou noman tellen here þou come of body myne."
0.90: (90) ¶ fforþ com þoo his trewe wijf wiþ sorou&yogh;, & care & drery lijf, And nei&yogh; for doel ded. 'Allas! she seide, my ioye cast, Kare & sorou&yogh; ben in me fast, As widewe wiþoute red. Al my welþe is fro me went, No womman is in swiche tourment In lengþe ne in brede. Al þis werlde, & it myne were, I wolde &yogh;iue it fer and nere, To seen his fairehede.
0.91: (91) ¶ 'It is no wonder of my doloure; Yshadewed is al my myroure [MS. myrouþe] , And lorne is my bri&yogh;thnesse; Myne herte may nou&yogh;th lange dure. Cursed worþe þou, dame auenture, þat doost me destresse! After fair weder falleþ reyn, After wynnyng wep ageyn, And care is after kysse, Erly to day by þe morowe, I ne wist of care ne of sorowe: To bale is tourned my blisse.'
0.92: (92) ¶ þapostoile & þe clergie, þemperoures & her chiualerie, Token þat confessoure, And leiden on a bere ri&yogh;th; ffair & wel hij habbeþ hym di&yogh;th, wiþ menske & honoure; To þe chirche of seint Bonefas, wiþ þe corps þai token þe pas wiþouten any soioure; þe belles alle a&yogh;ein hem rungen, Preostes & clerkes merily sungen wiþ þat swete floure.
0.93: (93) ¶ Noman may telle wiþ tunge þe miracles þat of hym sprunge As þai þat body bere; Deef & doumbe, halte & blynde, Alle mi&yogh;tten bote fynde, In maladie þat were; Men þat weren in palesye, Lunatik, oiþer in frenesie, Bote hadden þere. Swiche presse was þe poeple among, þemperoures mi&yogh;tten nou&yogh;th for þrong Beren forþ þe bere.
0.94: (94) ¶ þai biþou&yogh;tten hem in þis wyse, þat folk was ful of Coueitise, And tresore onon of sende, And casten aboute siluer & golde, Take it vp who þat wolde, Largely to spende. Nou&yogh;th for þan in euery strete þe presse was swiþe grete, þai mi&yogh;tten hem nou&yogh;th defende; þai leten lygge þat tresoure, And foloweden þat confessoure þat day to þe ende.
0.95: (95) ¶ Ri&yogh;th at seint Bonefas chirche, To seint Alexi þai gonne wirche A riche monument: Seuene dayes his frendes duelleden þere ffor his body þat lay on bere, And siþens hom þai went. His fader / his moder / & his wijf, Lyueden after in holy lijf Trewely wiþ gode entent. And whan þai dyeden alle þre, þai wenten wiþ solempnite To god omnipotent.
0.96: (96) ¶ þus ende & orde &yogh;ee han yherd, Of seint Alexi hou it ferd, wiþouten any lesyng. In þe worschip of god in glorie, Out of latyn is drawen þis storie, þorou&yogh; mi&yogh;th of heuene kyng. alle þat habben yherd his vye, God brynge hem to þe compaignye þere Aungels ben wonyynge; And sende vs, lorde, þi mylde mood; ffor þorou&yogh; þee spryngeþ al good wiþouten any endynge. Amen, Amen, Amen.
