1.2: [A]lle þat wolle a whyle here dwell, herkynnythe, and I woll yowe tell A tale Sone of grete pyte: Att rome, by-ffell in þat Cyte, There somtyme wonnyd a man, hys name was callyd eufemyan; he was ryche in all thyng, And euery day seruyd as a kyng; he had I-now&yogh;e of worlldys well, And seruantes with hym many and fele, Thre thowesant to hym were atend|aund, That weryd gold on here pendaunt. In hys owne hous euery daye, A custyume was that I schall saye: there boredes that were fayre spred, There pormen schulde be fede; Of all pormen of ylk a gate, there was none þat werned þ e yate. A wyfe he had, she hyght a gales, An holey woman withowten lees; She louyd god with all her myght, And seruyd hym bothe daye and nyght; She was of gode wyll, and hart Free To all þe dedes of charite. there she wollde clothe and fede, and helpe men at here nede. By twene theym chyllde had þey none, there fore they made mykell mon. theye were allwaye blythe and hende, In hope that god shollde hem sende Some maydyn chyllde, or some man, That theyre herytages myght hane; So long theye prayed with good entent, that a man chyllde god hem sent; whan they wyst þat hit was so, Chanse theye leuyd bothe twoo, Sythyn þey wollde for no need Com to gedur in Flesschely ded. Whan thys man chyllde was borne, Fayne were here frendys therforne; Theye bare the chylde to chirche A none, And crystenyd hyt in the Font stone. there theye callyd þe chylde Alexe; Sone hit throofe, and wele hit wex. Whan hit was vij yere olde and more, hys freendys sett hym wnto lore; he was sone Full goode of wytt, And wnderstode the holy wryte; he loued god in all his thought, And of thys worllde gaffe he nought; he sawe thys worllde was butt gylle, for hit showld laste but a whyle; neuerthe les whan he was elde, lone and felde For to wellde, hys fader puruyde hym a wyffe, Wit whome he soulde led hys lyffe; A mayden there was fayre and Fre, Com of þe rycheste of that cette. In holy chyrche vppon a daye They were spousyde in goddys laue; Atte here spousyng I wott there stode Beshoppys felle and prestes goode; Sythen theye made a mangery With all the beste of here aleye; All that comyn thyder þat daye theye were seruyd welle to paye, Com þey erley, com the late, theye wer neuer wernyd þe yate; there was nowder man nor knaue, Byt mete and drynke he myght haue. Euery man had there plente Of claret wyne and pymente; There was many a riche wyne, In sylluer and in golde fyne; Many a coppe and many a pece, with wyne wernage & eke of grece; And many A noder ryche vessell with wyne of gascoyne and of rochell. whan euyne com þat elke a gest was gone to bed to take hys rest, Eufemyan callyd hys sone Anone, And bad hym þat he shoulde gone In to hys chaumbur to hys fere, And cowmfort her in hys manere. Alex was to hym obedyent, and ded his faders comawndement; In to a chaumbur he com full ryght, And redy there he founde hys bryght, And toke here in his armys twoo, And downe they layde bothe twoo; 'dame,' he sayde, 'nou it ys soo, Of Flessche ar wee allso. Noue may we be gladde of þis lyffe, For thowe art bothe moder and wyffe; For allwaye rede þat hit so be, For nowe muste me wende frome the. Whylys I was yong I made a vowe, That I wyll Fullfell hyt nowe, For to wende a pylgremage, Noue woll I doo þat vyage, And þou schalt lewe here at home, agayne as goddys wyll I come.' he yaffe her a gyrdell and a ryng, all for a tokyng at þeyre departyng; And Forthe he went that elke nyght. To þe sse he come full ryght; The shipe was redy, and ouer went, wynde att wyll god hym sent. whan he come Into a Fer contre, he come into a ryche cytte, Knowyn he wollde in no wyse be Of no man þat shoullde hym see. In that cyte was an Image, That was lyke goddes wysage, Many a pylgryme had hit sought, For hit was neuer with honde wrought. Alex herd ther of than t[e]lle, Than thought he there to duell. A none he yaffe Frome hym awaye to powre men all hys monaye; And bought hym pore man ys wede, That none of theyme shoullde thak hede, And axed his met eorly and late, With poremen att the mynster yate. All the mete þat he myght gete, Bot euery day a melys mete To pore men gaffe A noone ryght, he lefft hym sylffe none ouer nyght. there dwellyd he xvij yere, And lede his lyffe in thys manere; his Fader and hys modyr bothe, Than he was to theyme Fvll lothe; his fadyr made gret dole and sorowe, Bothe on euen and on morowe. 'Alas!' he sayde, and wrong his honde, 'Why is my sonne went owte of lond? I wende haue hade of hym a knyght, with me to stonde In all my ryght; nowe ys he wente þat was my blysse, I west hym neuer do man a mys. Nowe haue I none of my lynage That maye welde myn herytage.' Than sayde his moder, and wepte full sore, 'Noue shall I see my sonne no more; I was full glade whan he was borne, nowe ys all my Ioye forlorne. I haue hade robbys maney and fayre, Nowe woll I next me were the ayre, Tyll I maye some tydynges here of my sone that was so dere.' than spake his wyffe, and wepte among. 'My leffe,' she sayde, 'was done wrong, he toke me in my fadyrs bowre, And brought me hydder with grete honouer. And he has me nowe for-sakyng, To Iesu cryst I wyll me takyne; Sorowe and morenyng may I well make, As the turtell dothe withowten his make. Ioyefull schall I neuer bee, Tyll I maye my leman see.' hys Fader send bothe fer and vyde Messengers on euery syde, To seke his sonne where he was went, Bothe Fer and nere where he was went. Sythen affter yt befell soo, Of messengeres there com too, Ryght to the Ryche Cete, There alex lywyd In pourte. As they com In to a strete, Alex com and shoulde hym mete; Sone knewe he þeyme fwll welle, And þey knewe hym neuer a dele. lowde he spake vnder hys hoode, 'For goddes lowe do me som goode;' Theye gaffe hym of theyre money, For goddes lowe there in the waye. whan Alex sawe þeye knwe hym nought, he thanked god in all hys thought. 'lorde,' he sayde, 'I thank the the grace þat thowe hast sent me; Myne owne men that shoullde bee, hate gewyn me of theyre cheryte.' Alex dwellyd styll there Fully xlij yere and more. To chyrche he went euery daye, his goode bedeyes there for to saye; In to that chyrche, with owtyn fayle, Was an Images of fayre entayele, Of owre lady þat is so Free, With here sonne wppon here knee; That Images spake, þat was so bryght, to the sexteyene vppon a nyght. 'Take,' sche sayde, 'my seruante swythe, he hathe me seruyd all hys lyeffe; Full offte he wolle to me lowthe, hit is no ryght þat he is withowte.' 'lady,' he sayde, 'I knowe hym nought, Nor I wott neuer where he schull be sought.' She sayde, 'he sitteþe eorly and late Withowtyn att the mynster yate.' Anon he owte of his slepe brayde, And thought what þe Image sayde. And forthe went the sextayne, And fownde alexknelyng In þe Rayne. Fayne was he that he hym founde, A-non he toke hym vpe be þe hande. 'A-ryse,' he sayde, 'my leve and dere, hit ys no ryght þat thowe sitt here. Com,' he sayde, 'my lady bade, And there of mayst þou be glade.' All that hard this tydynges, Theye worshippyd Iesu, hewyn kyng. Whan Alex sawe hit schulde be ryffe, hys penance and hys holy lyffe, here kepte he to haue mede, In this worllde for his goode deede; Bytt stylly he yeede a waye In to a-nodr dyuers contre. To þe se he cam in þat entente, In to spreusse he wollde haue wente; byt there com A storme of wynde & rayne, [MS. raynde] And droffe þe shipe home a gayne, That In a lytyll stonde they come Ryght to þe cyte of rome. Alex sayde þan with sympyll cher, 'Alas!' he sayde, 'wat do we here? Myght hitt haue bene affter me, here wollde I nought haue I-bee; Butt gode wollde hit myght befall I myght be in my fadris haull, So that I myght vnknowen be of hym and of his meyny.' Forthe he vent vpe be a strete, many a man there gan mete; But there was no man þat hym knwe, So was he lene and blake of hewe. There come his fader hyme agayne, With mayny a knyght and many a swane, Than com with hym on ylke a syde; Alex stode stelle theyme to a-byde. 'Syr,' he sayde, 'for goddes sake Wyll yee thys porman In thake? for his lowe þat dyed on Roode, Gywe me clethe and manys foode; and for his lowe þat went for the, God sende þe grace hym for to see.' This ryche man with stode þan, And callyd one of his owne men, And gaffe hym mete an dr[i]nk bothe, And with pore men hym to clothe. There dwellyd alex wythem alle, Sewentene yere in his Faders hall; There was no man, hye ne llawe, yongne owlde, þat hym myght knowe; his owne men for rebaundrye dyd hym manye a welonye. They hylde water wppon hys hede, And gaff hym þat was in the dyche levyd; But euer he hylde hym stylle, And Alle he suffyrde with goode wyll. A-gayne xvij wyntersende, Whane he schowlde owte of þis worllde wend, he prayd hym þat brout hys mete, Prev[i]ly he shoullde hym gete A lytyll ynke and perchemyne, And all hys lyffe he wrote there In. whan hit was wretyn, he hit Follde, And In his hand he gan hit hollde. And a none he dyed, I wys, And dyght his sowlle to hewyn blys. That ylke a daye in tym of masse, whan all fowlke att chirche was, A woyce cam frome þe trinite To the bysshope of that cyte. 'Com to me,' he sayde, 'þat woll swynke, And I schall gywe yowe met and drynke; 'Sek ye vpe my serwaunte, where þat he be, That he maye praye for this cete.' ollde and yonge, lesse and more, All hard this þat were there: For hit was no man, lewde ne leryd, But of this woyce he nas a-Feryd. Goddes seruaunte anon was sought, but who hit was þey knowe hym nought; That voyce sayde on that ylke a daye, And tolde hym redyly where he laye; 'In eufamyans hous,' he sayde, 'is he, That hathe my Serwaunt long I-be.' the besshope And þe emperour went in to euffamyans hous; They axyd hym of syche a man; he sayde he knwe there of noone. on of his seruaunttes was thane thore, That stode and lokeyd Alex by|fore. 'Syr,' he sayde, 'I trowe hit be That poreman þat yee toke to me, That long has bene in your hall, he is an holy man with all.' This ryche man went to hym a noone, And founde Alex ded as ony stone, But his vysage was allso bryght As the sonne on þe daye lyght. Than trowyd well eufemyan That he was an holey man; he callyd þe bysshopes & þe Empe|rowres To se þat cors so presyowse. In theye com a non ryght, And saue the body þat was so bryght; downe on knes theye fell thow, And oder many that were þere moo, And thankyd god In trinite, That theye myght his seruaunte see. The bysshope, as he stode hym nye, A perchement leffe in his honde he see, But he hyllde his hand so faste, That owte he myght hit natt wrast. 'Sonne,' sayde þe bysshope, 'I praye þee that in thye honde þoue lett me see; Synfulle all thou&yogh;e hit bee, I haue powre and dyngnytee For to lousse and for to bynde Thym þat I in syn Fynde. There Fore, sone, let me wetten what ys in thy bocke wrytyn.' The beshope toke þe boke so hynde, That Alex hys hond on bynde; the beshope þat Rolle red A non, That þey yt harde euerychone. There was there in redly tolde Alle hys lyfe, yong and olde. Whan hys Fader harde of thys, That he was hys sone I wys, 'lorde,' he sayde, 'howe maye þys bee? ys thys my sone þat I here scee? Sewentene yere wyt All, I had fynde hym in myn halle; I myght nat wyt for none Asaye, What he was, nyght nor daye. "leffe sone," he sayde, "why ded þou soo? Thowe saw I was For þe Full woo; for þowe were not At my wylle, And ewer more þou helde þe styll; Thyne own saruantes þat sholde be, myche harme ded þey to þee; Theye kest water on thyn hede, And gafe þe þat was in the dyche leuyde, And euer þou bare þe meke and lawe, For þat no man should þe there cnawe. In heuyn ther fore þou hast mede: Sonne, praye fore me, fore I haue nede."' hys moder lyued in In longyng, whan sche herde of thys tydyng, She com Forthe with A raply rese, As A lyon lept oute of A lees; She weppyd And cryde sore, As thay don þat arne woo. 'let me,' she sayd, 'my sone see; I Fed hym on myn owne kee.' whan she hym sawe, she Fylle downe, All was A waye here Resonne. whan she rose she stoode hym by, She kyssyde hym, And sayd on hye, 'Sonne,' she sayde, And wept Full sore, 'Nowe schall I speke with þe no more. Thowe hast be sought in meny A londe, With messengerys, And with sonde, Bot there was no man myght þe see, And euer þou sat be owre knee. lewe sonne, þou praye for mee, That I may þe in bleyss see.' hys wyfe þat was In chamber stokyn, Of þys tydynges harde sche spokyn; She com forthe in A sempyll pace, Sory, I wott, welle þat che was; She swonnyd at þe fryst syght, That on here was blake, þat rest was wyght. Than she sayd with mylde chere, 'Where hastowe be, my leman dere? Full long I myght þe A-byde, Fore thowe hast soughte pylgermages wyde. Thowe hast beene frome long, Forsothe I haue done þe no wrong; Wyghe þe speke nowe I ne maye, Nowe maye I weddowe be for Aye, I maye be weddow And mayden dde, And I haue done as ye me bade. Thowe weddest me to be þy Free, O nyght togeder when we were, Bot, good leuan, nowe praye for me That we to geder in blese maye be.' The folke come fast owte of þe cete, that ryche Relyke for to see. Sone in a A lytell stonde þer was Bothe grete throng And prece. The emperoure, that stode þer þoo, Sawe þe folke presyd ssoo; Sylvyr in þe strete þey cast, To lete the folke þat com so Fast, Bot of sylver yaffe þey no force, Alle held hem Fast to se þat corce. At þe last with trawayle borne hyt was To þe chyrche of seynt bonyfface. whan yt was to þe chyrche I-brought, A ryche tombe þere was wrought, Of marbyll And of ryche stonys, Craffetyly, And for þe nonce, of sylvyr And of golde coloure, They layd in þys Ryche tresowre. Sythen cam on to hys tombe Blynde And lame, dethe And dome, And other man many And felle: Thorowe grace of god þey hadden hell. Be thys holy man men may ssee, That god lowyght wele pouerte; he for soke thys worlde all bedene, And lowyd god, And yt ys sene he for soke hys Fader, Moder, And wyffe, And lyvyd A pore manys lyfe; Nowe is he in Ioye þat last[et]he Aye. God bryng us þere þat best maye. Praye wee All þat yt soo bee. Amen, Amen, For cheryte. explicit sante alex.

2.0: [ Vernon MS., leaf 44.] Sitteþ stille with-outen strif, And i wol tellen ou of a lyf Of an holy Mon; Alix was his nome. To seruen god þhu&yogh;te him no schome, þer-of neuer he ne blon. his fadur was a gret lording, Of rome a kyngus euenyng, and hihte Eufemian. Pore men to cloþe and fede, In al rome, þat riche þeode, such nas þer nan. eueri day were in his halle I-leid þreo bordus, forte calle pore Men to fede. Hem to serue he was wel glad; he dude as iesu crist him bad; he hoped þerfore to haue mede. whon he was serued bi and bi, þenne was he redi to go to his mete; ffor þe loue of Godes sone, wiþ Men of Religione wolde he sitte and ete. ¶ His wyf hi&yogh;te dame Agloes, to sigge soþ with-oute les, þat muche was to preyse. But heo dede þe same manere as dede hir lord, as &yogh;e may here, was heo nout at ese. Children bi-twene hem hedde þei none, þer-of to god þei maden heor mone boþe dai & niht. Iesu crist herde her bone, & sende hem a ful good sone, heor herte forte liht. So sone was bore þat blisful child, Alix boþe meke and Mild, and of maners hende. sone after wiþ gret hast, þei Auouwede boþe chast to heore lyues ende. þer-aftur was hit not longe, Alix couþe speke and gonge, and was i-set to lere; sone he was a wel god clerk, & muche he loued godus werk forte speke & here. As time as he bi-gon to belde, and was i-come to Monnes elde, him was chosen a wyf, Out of þe Emperors bour, a maiden god with gret honour, to wedden wiþ-oute strif. ¶ whon heo weren weddet þe furste ni&yogh;t, in godus lawe as hit was ri&yogh;t, & weren i-brou&yogh;t to house, Mekeliche he gon hire teche to drede god of sunne is leche, þat is Maidenes spouse. He preched hire with al his miht, of sunne heo scholde haue no pli&yogh;t, but holden hir Maidenhed. Of Iesu þat Maiden clene, in whom was neuere wem i-sene, heo schulde han hire med. Þenne tok he his gold ryng, and &yogh;af hit to þat Maide &yogh;ing, and seide to hire þus: 'Tac þis Ryng and kep hit me, til þat godes wille be, crist beo bi-twene vs.' ¶ whon he hedde don as i ou sei, he tok his leue & went his wei from þat Maiden fre. A parti god with him he tok, & al þat oþur he forsok, and wende him to þe séé. He fond schipes redi, to on he wente priueli, ouer forte fare. whon he was ouere on þe sond, he was in an vnkouþ lond, þer he con neuer are. He went him forþ with godus wille, a feir cite he com tille, þe nome i schal ou telle. Edissa hette þe cite, godus seruaunt forte be, þerinne forte dwelle. þe goodus þat he wiþ him brou&yogh;t of hem wolde he ri&yogh;t nou&yogh;t, he &yogh;af hem pore men. His Robe he &yogh;af þer he sauh nede, and cloþed him-self in pore wede, for no mon scholde him ken. He ede to A chirche hei, þer pore men seeten in þe wei, Almus forte take. AMongus hem he sat a-doun, and asked wiþ deuociun sum god for Godus sake. þat chirche was of vr ladi, þer-Inne was a gret celli, an ymage of hire sone, Maked of a wonder werk, þat nouþur lewed mon nor clerk ne mi&yogh;t wite hou hit was done; fforþi was þider gret sekyng of on and oþur, old and &yogh;yng, of al þat Cuntre, fforþi þe pore þat þer ware, Alle þe betere mi&yogh;te fare for heore Charite. Alix, of al þat mi&yogh;te he gete, nedliche bote he moste ete, he ne held to his bi-houe; To pore men þat wolde hit take, he &yogh;af hit for cristes sake, þat sitteþ us alle aboue. ¶ Nou is Alix dwelled þore: his fader atom sikeþ wel sore, and seiþ, Allas! Allas! His Moder wepeþ niht and day, & seiþ, Allas! & weila-wey, þat euere heo i-boren was. ¶ His wyf wepeþ and makeþ hir mone, & seiþ þat heo schal liuen alone as turtul on þe treo. Euermore with-outen Make, Ioye and blisse heo wole forsake til heo hire spouse i-seo. Nou is fader, with dreri chere, biddeþ his Men comen him nere, as þei wolde haue heore mede. He pre&yogh;eþ hem þat þei ben boun to wenden & sechen his deore sone, in eueriche a þeode; þat &yogh;e ne dwelle for no þing, er &yogh;e han herd sum god tiþing wher þat he be. Goþ nou forþ, and god ow spede, þerfore i schal, so God me rede, &yogh;iuen ou gold and ffe. ¶ Now wende þei forþ Alix sekande, vchone to diuerse lande, &yogh;if þei mi&yogh;te him winne. Summe of hem þorwh Godus grace, comen in-to þat ilke place þat Alix was Inne. He sat in pore Mennes rowe, þerfore þei couþe him not knowe, þei &yogh;euen him Charite. He tok hit wiþ mylde mod, and seide, 'Iesus, þat died on Rod, lorde, i þonke þe. Lord, i-þonked be þou ay, þat i haue beden þat ilke day, þat i may for þi sake; Of hem þat in myn owne lond, serued me to fot and hond, her Almus to take.' Nou þis Men þat weren out-sent, a&yogh;ein ham-ward þei hem went to sire Eufemiane. þei sworen alle bi heuene kyng of Alix herde heo noþing, as wide as þei hedden i-gone. In eueri lond [þat] we han ben we founde no mon þat him couþe sen, þat to him couþe vs wisse. "Nou, allas! þat i was boren; boþe haue i nou forloren mi Ioye and my blisse." ¶ In þis tale wol we non dwelle, of Alix wol we nou telle, þat riche pore mon. Alix was pore Monnes fere fulle seuentene &yogh;ere, fro þat he bi-gon, Sittinge in a chirche-&yogh;erde, among pore men an herde, in a simple wede. An ymage in þat chirche stoode of his Modur þat died on rode, for ur alre nede. ¶ Atte seuentene &yogh;eres ende spac and seide wordus hende þat ymage of tre, To þe wardein of þe chirche, & seide, "wardein, if þou worche eny-þing for me, "ffecche þou in mi sones nom, for seuentene &yogh;er hit is gon þat he haþ ben þer-oute. I warne þe witerli to dwelle her-in he is worþi, þer-of haue þou no doute; "He haþ serued heuene bri&yogh;t, þe holi gost in him is liht, & &yogh;iueþ him mi&yogh;t and grace, þat his pre&yogh;ere, with milde steuene, is swete & god & hei&yogh; in heuene bi-fore mi sone face." ¶ þenne seide þe wardeyn, 'ladi,' he seide, 'i wolde fayn, & i wuste whulche.' 'Go out faste as þou mai&yogh;t go, þou fyndest þer on & no mo, bring him in þat ilche.' þe wardein wente him out ful &yogh;are, he fond him redi sittinge þare, he brou&yogh;te him in ful sone. He seide, 'sire, &yogh;if hit be þi wille, þou art welcome nou vs tille, here-in schaltou wone. 'I was out aftur þe sent, þorwh vr ladies comaundement, þe in forte take; with muchel honour schaltou haue alle þing þat þou wolt craue, for þat ladies sake.' ¶ þenne þis word bi-gon to springe, & of him was gret spekynge, for his holynesse. þerfore he þou&yogh;te forte wende, to anoþur lond forte lende, þer me kneu&yogh; him lesse. þer wolde he no lengor beo: monnus honour forte fle, fro þat stude he wente In-to Laodiciane, forþ þe ri&yogh;te wey a-none, as Iesu crist him sente. In-to a-noþur lond he þou&yogh;t, godus wille til he hedde wrou&yogh;t, þer nomon hed him knowe. Assone as he was in þe se, forte wende þer he wolde beo, þe wynd bi-gon to blowe; þe wynt bi-gon þe schip to driue, til þei bi-gonne to aryue, as hit was godus wille, In rome, þer he was fed & boren, þer his woninge was bi-foren, of al him þhu&yogh;te hit ille. whon he sau&yogh; non oþur won, he bi-þou&yogh;te him sone Anon, wher him was best to be. To him-self he seide and þou&yogh;t, 'siþen þat Iesu haþ me brou&yogh;t in-to þis Cite, 'I con no beter red of alle, bote go to my fader halle, in pore mennes route. I may sitte vppon þe rowe; þer nis no mon schal me knowe, so longe ichaue ben oute. ¶ Vppon a day Eufemiane fro his paleis was he gane, and ham-ward he eode, with muche folk þat wel was di&yogh;t, boþe swein, [&] knaue, & kni&yogh;t, þat gode weren at nede. ¶ Alix þou&yogh;te he wolde him mete, & ron faste bi þe strete, til þat he him mette. whon he sau&yogh; þat he was nei&yogh;, with a vois [boþ] loude & hei&yogh;, Eufemian his fader he grette, And seide with a milde steuene, 'sire, for godus loue of heuene, haue merci of me. Icham a pilgrim pore & naked, þat haþ gret defaute ymaket, sire, as &yogh;e mowe se. Receiue me in-to þin halle, þer þi pore men aren alle; and graunte me þe mete, And i schal pre&yogh;e ni&yogh;t and day for þi sone þat is a-way, þat Iesu crist him gete, And grante þe, for his woundes fyue, þat þou mai seo him &yogh;it a-lyue þat was þin herte blisse; And þe, sire, withoute strif, Ioye of him in soule lyf, crist þe to him wisse.' ¶ þenne Eufemian with-stod, and grantede wiþ a milde mod þat pore mon his bone. He grantede him forte cloþe and feede, and bad his men heo scholden him lede to his hous al sone. He grantede him, as i ou telle, an hous al-one þer-in to dwelle, wiþ-outen eny fere; And a mon þat scholde him gete, & bringe him boþe drinke and mete, whon þat mester were. ¶ Nou Alix, as &yogh;e han [i]herd, is dwelled in his fader &yogh;erd, as a pore mon; In pre&yogh;ere, wakynge, and fastinge, he seruede Iesu, heuene kynge, in al þat he con. Seruauns þat were proude and &yogh;inge, þei driuen him ofte to skorninge, as heo eoden vp and doun; And ofte-siþes broþ of fissches, & watur þat þei wosschen in dissches, heo casten vpon his croun. Of al þe schome þat þei him wrou&yogh;te, he þonked Iesu þat him bou&yogh;te, & &yogh;af him mi&yogh;t þer-to. He was meke in alle þing, þer-of mi&yogh;te no mon him bring, for nou&yogh;t þat þei couþe do. ¶ Alix dwelled þere stille, as hit was Iesus cristes wille, seuentene &yogh;ere In his owne fader Inne; kneu&yogh; him non of al his kunne, neiþer fer ne nere. Atte seuentene &yogh;eres ende, he wuste he scholde heþen wende, þorw grace of þe holi gost, To Iesu crist, godus sone, in blisse with him forte wone, in lyf þat euer schal last. He gat him enke & parchemyn; al his lyf he wrot þer-in, as he hedde i-lyued here, And radde hit siþen vchadel, he þonked god, so mihte he wel, wiþ ful bliþe chere. ¶ Whon he hedde don as i ou say, vppon þe holy son[e]day þat com aftur nest, With muche Ioie & muche li&yogh;t his soule, þat was so feir & bri&yogh;t, went out of his brest. Whon þat gost was went to heuene, þer com a vois with milde steuene in-to an holy stede, þere as þe folk of Rome were, godus seruise forte here, & biddynge of holy bede, And seide þis word with-outen fayle: 'comeþ to me, þat haueþ trauayle or tene for mi sake; Comeþ to me, i schal ou fille with ioy & blisse, & al or wille, þat neuermore schal slake.' Whon þei hedde þis wordus herd, þei weren vchone sore a-ferd, & fullen a-doun to grounde. As þei le&yogh;e & hudde heor face, þer com eft, þorw godus grace, in a luytel stounde, Anoþer steuene milde & meke, & bad þei schulde ris vp, & seke A godus mon of Rome, 'þat &yogh;e mowe, þorw&yogh; his pre&yogh;ere, of his godnes ben partinere atte day of dome.' ¶ þei risen Al vp with bliþe chere, & sou&yogh;te boþe fer and nere, bi wei and [eke] bi strete. And for noþing þat þei wrou&yogh;te, with þat relik þat þei sou&yogh;te mou&yogh;te þei nowhere mete, Til þat vois, with wordes meke, com a-&yogh;ein & bad hem seke in Eufemians house; ffor þere scholde þei sone fynde þat scholde hele doumbe & blynde, a relik preciouse. ¶ þen þei ede sone anan, & asked sire Eufemian &yogh;if he kneu&yogh; such a mon. He onswerde ful rediliche, 'i sigge ou lordingus sikerliche of such ne wot i non.' ¶ þenne wente forþ þe Emperours, Archadius & honorius, & Inocent þe Pope, [Pope eras't ] Anon to Eufemians in,— er þei weore þer, wolde þei not blin,— with hem a god gret frape. þen com a knaue sone a-nan, & seide to sire Eufemian, 'go we, sire, i rede, And loke, sire, at oure pilgrime, þat &yogh;e han fed in long tyme, wher he beo quik or dede. '&YOGH;if he be ded þat was so meke, he is þat mon þat þei seke, i wot, with-outen drede. He was a mon of holy lif, of him com neiþer cheste ne strif, ne vuel word ne dede.' Whon Eufemian hedde þis herd, he ron to loke hou Alix ferd, in-to his hous ful ri&yogh;t. He fond him ded whon he com þare, his visage þer hit lay al bare, as sonne hit schined bri&yogh;t. In his hond he heold a skrit, Eufemian sturte him forþ as tit, to wite what was þer-Inne. Bote with non scunes ginne of þe hond þat hit was Inne mi&yogh;te he hit not out winne. ¶ Whon he mihte no betere spede, to þe Emperour he ede, and tolde þat tiþande. þenne come þei boþe forþ god pas, til þei come þer hit was, þe dede cors liggande. whon þei come in-to þe hous, þis Emperours þei seiden þus, and on þis Maneere: 'þau&yogh; we for sunne are vnworþi, we han kepinge not forþi of þeos londes heere. 'And þis Mon þat we pope [pope eras't ] calle, haþ þe pouwer of vs alle, and of al holichirche; fforþi diliuere vp þat scrite, þat we þer-þorwh mai seo and wite hou we schul with þe worche.' ¶ whon þei þus hedde iseid heor wille, þe pope [pope eras't ] leide his hond þer-tille, & he þenne let hit go. Anon þe pope [pope eras't ] let rede hit þere, bi-foren alle þat þer were, heringe his fader Also. ¶ whon his fader hedde herd hit red, he was a-wondred & a-dred, for serwe he was nei&yogh; ded. As mon þat hedde þe deþes wounde, he fel a-doun to þe grounde as heui as þe led. whon he hedde longe i-leyn, & his stat was comen a&yogh;ein, he made reuþful chere. He tar his cloþus & drou&yogh; his her, with delful cri & siking sor, þat del hit was to here. Muche deol hit is to telle, hou&yogh; he on þat bodi felle of weopyng blon he nouht. He seide, 'Allas! mi dere sone, hou mi&yogh;test þou þus longe wone with me þat kneu&yogh; þe nouht? Allas! nou hastou dwelled here al þis seuentene &yogh;ere in myn owne Inne; And þou hast boren þe so lowe, þat þou woldest neuere ben a-knowe þat þou wer of mi kinne. Allas! allas! and weilawai, þat euere I a-bod þis day, þis serwe forte seo. I wende haue had of þe solas in myn elde; Allas! Allas! for deol ded wol i beo.' ¶ whon his Moder herde of þis, heo sturte forþ in haste i-wis, As A lyonesse; with hirself heo ferde to wonder, heo ter hir cloþus al in sunder, in a gret woodnesse. Heo drou&yogh; hir her as heo weore wod, & seide, 'for him þat died on rod, Men, &yogh;e &yogh;iue me way, þat I mai to mi sone go; was neuer Moder half so wo as me is þis day. &YOGH;if me roum, & let me se þe bodi þat was boren of me, and fed of my breste. Let me come þat cors to, for wel &yogh;e witen hit is skil so þat i beo hit nexte.' Whon heo mi&yogh;te nei&yogh;e hit neer, heo fel þer-on with deolful cher, & seide, 'Allas! mi sone, Whi woldestou þus with us fare, to leten vs dwellen in serwe & care? whi hastou þus done? þou hast i-se&yogh;en þi fader and me wepen & maken gret del for þe, boþe erly and late; And þou hast seuentene &yogh;er vnknowen i-dwelled mid vs her, in pore beggers state.' Ofte-siþes heo fel doun on þat dede cors al in swoun, and custe hondes and feet; And þat face þat was so swete, heo custe hit & mad hit wete with teres þat heo leet. Heo seide, 'allas! þat me is wo, þou were my sone with-outen mo, wepeþ alle wiþ me. Ichaue þe fed moni a day, Allas! sone, weilaway, þat i ne knewh not þe. þou mist haue be a gret lordyng, and ben honoured as a king, &yogh;if hit hedde beo þi wille. Nou hastou had despit and wrong of þi þralles euer among, and boren hit ful stille. Allas! ho schal &yogh;iue to me welle of teres to wepe for þe boþe dai and niht? Allas! allas! me is wo, icholde myn herte wolde breken a-two, þat i sai&yogh; nou þis siht.' ¶ þenne com forþ a dreri þing, i-cloþed in cloþus of mournyng, þat was his owne wyue. Heo wepte þat pite was to se, and seide, 'Allas! þat wo is me, þat euere hedde I lyue. Nou al my ioye a-wei is gon, er hedde i hope, nou habbe i non to seon him a-lyue. Nou am i widewe, allas! þe stounde, serwe haþ &yogh;iue myn herte a wounde, þat me to deþ wol driue. Allas! what is me to rede, mi Muror is broken & is dede, þat my likynge was Inne. Hope of ioie nou haue I loren, & serwe is newed me beforen þat neuermore schal blinne.' Al þe folk þat stod be-side, þat sei&yogh; heore serwe so vnride, a wepten ful tenderliche. þer was non þat mi&yogh;te hem holde, Mon ne wommon, &yogh;ong ne olde, and þat was no feorliche. ¶ þe pope [pope crosst through ] com, & þe Emperours bad bringe him forþ out of þe hous & lei him on A bere, And bar him wiþ solempnete, forþ Amidde þe cite, & cri&yogh;inge þat almi&yogh;te here, And seide, 'come seoþ þat holi mon þat &yogh;e haue sou&yogh;t euerichon, here he is in þis place. He is founden, and he is here, þat holi bodi on a beere, þorwh help of godus grace.' Alle þat wusten of þat cri, þei ornen þidere wel hasteli, þei tolde þeron nout a lyte. An Alle þe seke þat þer were, þat mi&yogh;te touche þat bodi þere, þei weren hole as tite. þe blinde hedde þere of him here si&yogh;t, woode of him heore wit fol ri&yogh;t, þe halt here limes hole Anon. Hit was non þat þider mi&yogh;te winne, what seknes þei were inne, þat þei were hole vchon. ¶ whon þe Emperours sai þe wonder þei toke þe bere & eode þer-vndur, with the Pope [ crosst out ] helpande; ffor þei wolde be i-mad holi, þorwh beringe of þat bodi, þei toke þe bere in hande. þei made sowen in þat cite gold & seluer gret plente; and þat was for þis skil þat þe folk scholde hem with-drawe, and þat auayled not worþ an haue, þei tok no tent þer-til. þei preced euer neer and neere, forte come to þat bere þat þe cors lay Inne. þei precede wiþ so gret fors þat vnneþe with þe holi cors, to chirche mi&yogh;te þei winne. ¶ whon þei come to þe chirche, A toumbe of gold þei lette worche of preciouse stones. In A schort tyme hit was diht, ful richeliche and Al ari&yogh;t þei leide þer-in his bones. whon þat holi cors was leid in þat toumbe þat wel was grei|þed, wiþ ful gret honour, To alle þat weren in þat place þer com out, þorwh godes grace, a ful swete odour; So swote felede þei neuer non, as wyde as þei hedden gon, of no spicerie. þenne worschupeden heo Alle with o steuene, Iesu, godus sone of heuene, and his Modur Marie. Iesu crist, þorwh þe prei&yogh;ere of him þat we haue of told here, &yogh;if þi wille hit be, Graunt vs alle god endyng, and in heuene a wonyng. AMEN par Charite.
2.1: [ Laud MS. 108, leaf 233, back .] VITA CUIUSDAM SANCTI VIRI NOMINE ALEX. OPTIMA VITA. Sitteþ stille wiþouten strif, And I schal telle &yogh;ou þe lif Of an holy man. Alex was his ry&yogh;tte name; To serue god þoute him no schame, & þerof neuere he ne blan. his fader was a gret lording Of rome, a kynges euening, & hy&yogh;tte sire Eufemian. Pore men to cloþe & fede, In al rome, þat riche þede, Swich ne waster non. Eche day were in his halle Leyd þre bordes, forto calle Pore men to fede. Hem to serue he was wel glad, & dede as Iesu crist him bad; þerfore he hopede han mede. When þei were serued by & by, þane at arst was he redy To gon to his mete; þanne in drede of godes sone, Wiþ men of religione He wolde sitte & ete. His wif hy&yogh;tte dame Agles, To seye þe soþe wiþoute les, þat meche was to preyse; Bote &yogh;e my&yogh;tte do þe same maner þat dede hire lord, as y seyde er, Was &yogh;e nat wel atayse. Child hem bi-twene ne hadde þei non; þer-fore to god he maden here mon, Boþe be day & ny&yogh;the; Iesu crist herde here bone, & sente hem a ful god sone, here hertes forto ly&yogh;the. When he was bore, þat blisful child, Alex, boþe mek & myld, And of maneres hende: A litel after, wiþ greth hast þei a-voweden to him chast, To here lyues ende. þer-after was it nat lange: Alex coude speke & gange, And was set to lere. Sone he was a ful good clerk, & meche he louede godes werk fforto speke & here. Sone whan he gan to belde, & forto comen to mannes elde, him was chosen a wif, Out of þe emperoures bour, A mayde good, of greth honur, To wedde wiþ-oute strif. Whan þei were wedded þe ferste ny&yogh;th In godes [lawe], as it was ry&yogh;th, & was I-brouth to house: Mek[e]liche he gan hire teche, To drede god, of sinne leche, þat is maydenes spouse. he prechede hire wiþ al his my&yogh;th: Of s[i]nne &yogh;e scholde hauen no ply&yogh;th, Bote kepe hire maydenhod; & of iesu, þat mayde clene, In whom was neuere wem I-sene, &yogh;e scholde habbe hire mede. þanne tok he his gold ring, & &yogh;af þat mayde, þat was &yogh;ing, & seyde to hire þus: 'Tak þis ring, & kep it me, Til þat godes wille be, God bi-twene vs.' Whanne he hadde ido, as [I] &yogh;ou sey, He tok his leue & wente his wey fro þat mayde fre; A parti of his good he wiþ him tok, And al þat oþer he for-sok, he wente to þe see. He fond schipes redely; To on he wente priueli, ouer forto fare; He seyde he was a chapman, & preyde, he moste wiþ hem gon, &yogh;if þat here schip were &yogh;are. fforþ he wente wiþ godes wille; A fair cyte he com vn-tille; þe name I schal &yogh;ou telle: Edissa hatte þat cite; Godes seruant þer to be, þer-inne wolde he dwelle. þe goodes þat he wiþ him brougth, Of hem ne wolde he ry&yogh;th nowth, Bote &yogh;af hem pore menne; his robe he &yogh;af þer he sey nede, & cloþede him-sulf in pore wede, ffor noman scholde him kenne. he &yogh;ede to a churche-&yogh;ate, þer pouere men sete in þe gate, Almesse forto take; Among hem he sat a-doun, & Askede wiþ deuocion Sum good for godes sake. þat churche was of oure leuedy; þer-inne was a greth selly, An ymage of hire son, Maked of a wonder werk, þat neyþer lewed man ne clerk Niste hou it was don. þerfore was þider greth sekyng Of on & oþer, old & &yogh;ing, Of al þat countre; ffor-þi þe pouere þat þer were, Alle þe betere my&yogh;tte fare þoru here charite. Alex, of þat he my&yogh;tte gete Nedliche bote þat him-self wolde ete he ne held to his by-houe; To pouere men þat wolde it take, Al he &yogh;af for godes sake, þat is in heuene A-boue. Nou is Alex dwelled þere; his fader at hom seyet&yogh; sore, & seyþ 'allas! allas!' his moder wepuþ ny&yogh;th & day & seyþ 'allas & weylawey, þat euere &yogh;he born was.' his wif wepþ & makeþ hire mone, & þus [&yogh;he] schal lyuen allone, As turtle opon þe tre, Euere-more wiþoute make; Ioye & blisse &yogh;e wile for-sake, Til &yogh;e hire spouse se. Nou his fader wiþ dreri chere He biddeþ his men him comen nere, Als þei willen hauen þere mede, & preyeþ hem þat þei ben boun, To wende & sechen his dere sone In euerich ilk a þede. 'þat &yogh;e ne dwelle for no þing, Ar &yogh;e hauen herd sum tyding, Where þat he be; Goþ nou swyþe, & god &yogh;ou spede! þerfore I schal, so god me rede, &yogh;iuen &yogh;ou gold & fee.' Nou gon þei forþ Alex sekynd In diuerse londes to here tyding, &yogh;if þei him my&yogh;tte wynne; Somme of hem, þoru godes grace, Comen into þat ilke place þer Alex was Inne. he sat in pore mene rowe; þerfore couden he hym nat knowe; he &yogh;af him charite; & he it tok wiþ milde mod, And seyde 'Iesu, þat deyde on rod, Louerd, I þanke þe! Louerd, i-her[i]d be þou ay! þat i haue beden þat ilke day, þat I may, for þi sake, Of hem þat in myn owene lond Serueden me to fot & hond Here Almesse forto take.' Nou þese men þat were out-sent, a&yogh;en homward þei ben I-went To sire eufemian. þei swore to him be heuene king: Of Alex herde þei no tyding, As wyde as þei hadde gan. 'In eche a lond þan haue we be, We ne founden no man þat couþe him se, þat to him coude vs wisse.' 'Allas, he seyde, þat he was born! boþe [boþo MS.] haue I nou for-lorn Mi ioye & ek my blisse.' In þis tale wille we nat dwelle, Bote of Alex wile we telle, þat riche pore man. Alex was pouere mannes fere ffulli seuentene &yogh;ere, fro þat he bi-gan, Syttynde in a churche-&yogh;erd Amonges oþere men an herd In a simple wede. An ymage in þat cherche stod, Of his moder þat deyde on rood ffor oure alþres nede. At þe seuentene &yogh;eres ende, Spak & seyde wordes hende, þat ymage of tre, To þe wardeyn of þe churche, & seyde: 'wardeyn, &yogh;if þou werche Enyþing for me, ffeche þou In my sones man, ffor seuentene &yogh;er it is i-gan þat he haþ ben þer-oute; I þe warne wyterly, To duelle her-inne he is worþi; Whar-of ne haue no doute. he haþ deserued heuene bry&yogh;th, þe holy gost is in him ly&yogh;th & &yogh;iuen him my&yogh;tte & grace, þat his preyer wiþ milde stephene Is good & swete & mylde in heuene Byfore my sones face.' þanne ansuerede þe wardeyn & seyde: 'lauedi, I wille ful fayn, and I wiste wilk.' 'Go owt so swiþe so þou mayst go, þou ne fyndest þer no mo, Bryng him [in] þat ilk!' þe wardeyn wente him out ful &yogh;are, he fond [him] redy sittinde þere, he brougthe him In ful sone; And [seyde]: 'sire, &yogh;if it be þi wille, þou art welcome vs vntille, Her-Inne schaltou wone; I was out after þe i-sent þoru our lauedies comandement, [MS. comandemement] þe in forto take. Mechul honur schaltou haue, & alle þing þat þou wilt craue, ffor þat lauedies sake.' Whan þis word be-gan to springe, þat of him was a gret spekyngge ffor his holinesse, Sone he þoutthe forto wende, To oþer londe forto lende, þere men him knewe lesse. þere ne wolde he lengere be, Mannes honur forto fle, ffro þat stede he wende Anon to laodician fforþ þe ry&yogh;tte wey anon, Als iesu crist him sende. To A-noþer lond he þout, Godes wille to han I-wrouth, þer noman ne hadde him knowe. Als swiþe as he was in þe se fforto wende þer he wolde be, þe wynd be-gan to blowe. þe wynd be-gan þe schip to dryue Til þat he be-gonne to Aryue, Als it was godes wille, In rome þer he was fed & born, þer his wonyng was be-forn, þei al him þoute ille. Whan he saw non oþer won, he be-þoutte him sone anon, Whare him was best to be; To him-sulf he seyde & þou&yogh;th: 'Siþen Iesus me haþ hider i-brou&yogh;th In-to þis cite, I ne can no betere red of alle, Bote gon to my faderes halle In pore mannes rowte, I may sitte in þe rowe, þer nis no man þat me schal knowe: So longe Ich haue ben oute.' Vpon a day sire Eufemian ffro þe paleys was he gan, And homward he &yogh;ede, Wiþ mikel folk þat wel waren dy&yogh;th, Boþe knaue sweyn & knyth, þat gode were in nede. Alex þoute he wolde him mete; & ran forþ faste be þe strete Vn-til þat he him mette; Whan he say þat [he] was ney, Wiþ a voys boþe loud & hey, Sire Eufemian he grette, & seyde wiþ a mylde stephene: 'Sire, for godes loue of heuene haue merci on me! Ich am a pilgrym pore & nakud, þat gret defaute haþ I-maked, Sire, as &yogh;e may I-se. 'Resceyue me into þin halle, þere þine pore men ben alle, & graunte me þe mete! And I schal preye ny&yogh;th & day for þi sone þat is awey, þat Iesu crist him þe gete, '& grante þe, for his wondes fiue, þat þou myttest him se in þine lyue, þat was þin herte blisse, &, sire, to habbe wiþoute strif Ioye of him in soule & lif, Crist þe til him wisse.' þanne eufemian þer wiþstod, & grantede him wiþ milde mod, þe pore man his bone; he grantede him to cloþe & fede, & bad his men he scholde him lede To his hous as sone; And grauntede him, as [I] &yogh;ou telle, An hous allone þer-in to dwelle Wiþ-outen eny fere, & a man þat scholde him gete And bringe him boþe drynk & mete, Whan þat mester were. Nou Alex, As &yogh;e habbeþ i-herd, Is dweld in his fader &yogh;erd As a pore man. In preyere of fasting & waking, he seruede Iesu, heuene kyng, In al þat he can. Seruant&yogh; þat were proute & &yogh;ungge, him dryuen ofte to heþingge, As he &yogh;ede vp & doun; & ofte-siþes, broþ of ffissches, & water, as he wessch here dissches, þei caste vp-on his croun. Of al þe schame þat þei him wrou&yogh;the, He þonkede Iesu, þat him bouthe, & &yogh;af him my&yogh;tte þerto; He was þolemod in alle þinge, þer-out ne my&yogh;tte no man him bringe, ffor nowth þei couden do. þere dwelde Alex stille, As it was Iesu cristes wille, Seuentene &yogh;er; In his owene faderes In, kneu him non of al his kyn, Neyþer fer ne ner. At þe seuenteþe &yogh;eres ende, he wiste he scholde hennes wende, þoru grace of þe holy gast, To Iesu crist, godes sone, In blisse of heuene ay forto wone, In þe lif þat euere schal last. // he gat him enke & parchemyn; And al his lif he wrot þer-In, þat he had lyued here, And radde it seþen eueri-del, & þonkede god, so my&yogh;t he wel, Wiþ ful bliþe chere. Whan he hadde I-do as I &yogh;ou say, Vpon þe holy soneday þat com after nest, Wiþ meche ioye & meche ly&yogh;th, his soule, þat was so fair & bry&yogh;th, Wente out at his brest. When his soule was went to heuene, þer com a vois wiþ milde stephene In-to an holy stede, þer al þe folk of rome were, Godes seruise forto here, To bidden holy bede, And seyde þes wordes wiþoute faille: "Comeþ to me, þat haueþ trauaille Oþer charge for my sake! Comeþ to me, I schal &yogh;ou fille Wiþ ioye & blisse at al &yogh;oure wille, þat neuere mor schal slake." Whan þe folk hadde þat word herd, þe[i] were echone sore a-fered & fullen doun to grounde; As þei leyen & hedde here face, þar com owth, þoru godes grace, In a litel stounde, Anoþer stephene mylde & meke, & bad hem vp arise, & seke A godes man of rome, 'þat &yogh;e mowe, þoru his preyer, Of his godnesse ben partener At þe day of dome.' // þei risen alle wiþ bliþe chere & southe boþe fer & nere, Be weye & ek be strete; Bote for noþing þat þei wrouth, Wiþ þat relyk þat þei south, My&yogh;tte þe[i] nowar mete; Til þat voit&yogh; wiþ worde meke Com a&yogh;en, & bad hem seke In sire Eufemianes hous, 'þer &yogh;e scholle sone fynde þat schal hele dombe & blynde, A relik precious.' þanne wente þei forþ a-nan, & askeden sire eufemian: &yogh;if he knew swich a man. he ansuerede redely & seyde: lordingges, sikerly, Of swich ne wot I non. þanne wente forþ þe emperuors, Archadious & honorius, & Innocent þe pape, Anon to sire Eufemia[n]s In; Til þei come þere, wolde þei nat blyn; Wiþ hem wente forþ greth frape. þanne cam forþ a knaue anan, & seyde to sire eufemian: 'Go we, sire, I rede, And loken [sire] at &yogh;oure pilgrim þat &yogh;e han fed of long tym, Wher he be quik oþer dede. '&yogh;if he be ded þat was so meke, he is þat man þat þei seke, I wot wiþ-oute drede: he was a man of holy lif, Of him com neuere stout ne strif, Ne wikke word ne dede.' Whanne eufemian þat i-herde, he &yogh;ede to loke hou alex ferde, To his hous ful ry&yogh;th; he fond him ded whan he com þare, his face, þer it lay on bere, As sonne schinede bry&yogh;th. In his hond he fond a skript, Eufemian &yogh;ede to him as tyd To wyte what was þer-Inne; Bote for nones kynnes gyn out of þe hond þat it was In My&yogh;tte he it nat wynne. Whan he ne my&yogh;tte no betere spede, To þe emperour he &yogh;ede, & tolde him þat tydingge. þane comeþ he a&yogh;en god pas, Til he comen þar he was, þe dede corps liggynde. Whan þei comen Into þe hous, þe emperour seyde þus And on þis manere: "þei we for synne ben vn-worþi, We han to kepyng nawth for-þi of þese londes here; "And þis man þat we pope calle, haþ þe kepyng of vs alle & of holy churche; þerfore deliure vs vp þe skryt, þat we þere-þoru may se & wyt hou we schulle wiþ þe werche." Wen þei hadde þus seid here wille, þe pope leyde his hond þer-tille, Alex þan let go. þe pope as tyd let rede it þere Byfore al þo þat þer were, herynde his fader also. Whan his fader herde it rede, he was for-wondred & for-drede, for sorwe he was ney ded; As man þat hadde deþes wounde He fel swingge doun to grounde, Heuy so any led. Wan he hadde longe I-leyn, þan his stat bi-com a-gayn, & made reuly chere; he rof his brest, he drou his her wiþ duelful cry & syking sor, þat pite it was to here. Meche doel it is to telle hou he on þat body felle, of weping blan he nouth. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . no gap in the MS. 'Allas nou hastou duelled here Alle þese seuentene &yogh;ere In myn owene In, & þou hast boren þe so lowe, & noldest neuere ben o knowe þat þou were of oure kyn. Out ay, allas, & weylawey, þat I euere a-bod þis day þis sorwe forto se! I wende han had of þe solas In myn elde, allas, allas, for doel ded willi be!' Whenne his moder herde of þis, &yogh;e sterte forþ in haste i-wis as a leonesse, Wiþ hire sulf sche ferde to wonder, Sche rof hire cloþes al to sonder In a gret wodnesse; Sche drou hire her as sche were wod, & seyde: "for him þat deyde on rod, &yogh;e men, &yogh;iueþ me wey, þat I may to my sone go! Was neuere moder half so wo As me is þis day. &yogh;iueþ me roum, & lat me se þe body þat was boren of me, & fed was of my brest! leteþ me come þe cors vntil, ffor &yogh;e wyten þat it is skyl þat I be it next." Whan sche my&yogh;tte neyh it nere, Sche fel þer-on wiþ sori chere, & seyde: "allas, my son, Whi hauest tou þus wiþ vs fare, Suffred vs for þe sorwe & care, Whi hastou þus don? þou hast i-seye þi fader & me Wepen & maken gret doel for þe Boþe erly & late; And tou hast seuentene &yogh;er Vn-knowe duelled wiþ vs her In pouere beggeres state." Ofte-siþe &yogh;e fel doun opon þe body al I-swoun, & kissede honden & feet; & þat face þat was so swete, Sche it kiste, & made it wete Wiþ teres þat sche let. Sche seide: "allas, what me is wo! þou were my sone wiþ-oute mo; Wepeþ al folk wiþ me! I haue þe fed many a day; Allas owt & weylawey, þat I ne knew nout þe! þou my&yogh;test han ben a greth lording, & honured als a kyng, &yogh;if it hadde ben þi wille; Nou hauest þou had despit & wrong Of þine þralles euere among, & bor[e]n it ful stille. Allas, who schal &yogh;iue to me Welle of teres to wepe for þe Boþe day & ny&yogh;th? Allas allas, what me is wo! I wolde myn herte it breke a-tuo þat I ne saye nowth þis sy&yogh;th." // þanne cam forþ a drery þing, I-clad in cloþes of mournyng, It was Alex wif; Sche wep þat pite was to se & seyde: "Allas, ful wo is me, þat euere hadde I lyf! Nou al my ioye awey is gon. Er hadde I hope, now haue I non To sen him on lyue; Nou am I wydewe, allas þat stounde! Sorwe haþ &yogh;iuen myn herte a wounde þat me to deþe schal dryue. // Allas! what is me to rede? And alle þe sike þat þer were, þat my&yogh;tte touche þe body þere, þei were hol als tyd. // þe blynde, of him hadden here sy&yogh;th; þe wode, here wyth hadde ful ry&yogh;th; þe halte, here lymes lele. þer ne was non þat þider my&yogh;te wynne, What syknesse þat þei were Inne, þat þei ne hadde here hele. // Whan þe emperour him say þat won|der, he [MS. ho] tok þe bere & &yogh;ide þer-vnder, Wiþ þe pope he wende, ffor he wolde ben mad holy þoru þe bering of þat body, he tok þe bere in hande. // he let sowe in þe cyte Gold & siluer gret plente, & þat was for þis skyl, ffor þe folk scholde hem wiþdrawe; bote þat a-vaillede nat an hawe, þey toke no tent þer-til. þei preceden euere ner & nerre, fforto comen to þe bere þat þe corps lay Inne; þei preseden þerto wiþ gret fors, þat vnneþe wiþ þat holy cors To churche my&yogh;te þei wynne. // Whanne þei comen to þe churche, A toumbe of gold he leten wurche Wiþ preciouse stones; In seue dayes it was dy&yogh;th fful richeliche al a-ry&yogh;th, þei leyden þer-inne þe bones. Wan þat holy cors was leyd In-to þe toumbe richeliche I-grey|þud Wiþ ful meche honour: To alle þat were in þat place þer com owt þoru godes grace A ful swete odour. So swete ne smelde þei neuere non, Als so wyde as þey hadden gon, Of no spiserye. þei worchipeden him alle wiþ o stephne & þankeden Iesu crist of heuene & his moder Marye. // Nou Iesu crist þoru þe preyer of þat cors seint I tolde &yogh;ou her, &yogh;if þi wille it be, Graunte vs alle god endyng, And in heuene a wonying! In Rome was a doughty man, þat was cleped Eufemyan, Man of mychel myghte; Gold & Siluer he hadde .y.-nouh, Halles & boures, oxen & plouh, And wonder wel it dyghte. ¶ ffor all þe seke of þe burhg ffaste were y.-sough[t] þoruhg, & brouht to his house. he let hem bedde wel & fede, And to hem tok goed hede, him-self & his spouse. þe man hadde a god wif, She ne louede flyt ne stryf In al hire liue. þe sekemen ofte she fedde, & softe brou&yogh;t hem obedde, blessed beo she to wiue. ¶ þei were to-gedere &yogh;eres two, & so þei were somdel mo, With-outen any blede. þei bede god with herte gode, þat hem sende suich a fode to serue hem & drede. And Iesu Crist, þat is so mylde, &YOGH;af hem grace, she was with chylde, Þe gode lauedye. Boþe be day, & be nyght, &YOGH;erne þei þonked our dright, & Seinte Marie. ¶ þo þe child y.-bore was, þei þonked Crist of his grace wiþ glad chiere. Also as þe wone was, As þei coude with softe pas, to chirche þei it bere. // þo þis child to chirche com, To afong Cristendom, as þe ryght is, his fader & his moder þo Swiþe bliþe were bo, & cleped it Alexijs. ¶ þei nadde bot þilk sone, therfore as it is þe wone, þei loued it þe more. þo he was old, &yogh;eres seuen, þei him wissed with mylde steuen, & sette him to lore. ¶ þis child wex & wel they, Cristes help him was ney, & þat was wel y.-sene; for more he lerned in on &yogh;er þan any of his oþer fere dide in &yogh;eres tene. // As sone as he vnderstod Werldes blisse nas not god, Who it vnderstode, Werldes wele he forsok, & to Iesu. In-to vncouþ lond þou most fare, And soffry moche tene þare, Al for sone myne. ¶ And suþþe þou shelt a-&yogh;e come, And in þy fader hous [shalt] wone, And þer-ynne fyne.' þis childis fader fel on elde, And his moder godis helde, &yogh;eres hadde fele. Hy wolde here sone sholde wyue, To gladen hem in þis lyue, And haue worldis wele. ¶ Hy by-so&yogh;ten him a mayde, þat witty was and ful of rede, I-come of he&yogh;e kenne; Woman hy was of hewe bri&yogh;t, Hy þo&yogh;te on crist day and ny&yogh;t, And wiste here fro senne. ffor þo hy were to-gydere y-come, þis mayde and þis &yogh;onge gome, In godis lawe, ¶ þer was game and moche gle, Ac, al for-soþe ich telle þe, Ne eysede hem no plawe. þe day was go, þe ny&yogh;t was come; þo seyde þe fader to þe sone, With wel glade chere, 'Op arys, þou sone myn, And go [þou] in-to boure þyn, To glady þyne fere.' ¶ þo he was in-to boure y-bro&yogh;t, He by-held þat may swaþel & to&yogh;t Of bri&yogh;te hywe. Sone turnde he his þo&yogh;t, In fondynge he was y-bro&yogh;t, His care be-gan al nywe; He si&yogh;te, & made sorweful chere, Teres ouer his whyte lere Bytere he let falle. ¶ Ne my&yogh;te him gladye his fere, With wordes ne with fayre chere, þat stod y-shrud in palle; þo it alles op a brake, þe &yogh;onge man to his brede spake, With wel fayre bere: 'Leman, haue guod day, No lenger ich ne may With þe by sene here. ¶ Wende ich mot fer out of londe, And soffry tene & peynes stronge, My synnes to bete. Bothe ich mot, for godis sake, ffader & moder myne forsake, And þe þat art so swete.' þo hy hadde y-herd þe tale, Hire blesse turnde to bale, A-swo&yogh;e hy fel to grounde. ¶ þo hy of swo&yogh;enynge a-ros, Wel sore here a-gros, With care hy was y-bounde. Sone so hy my&yogh;te op-stonde, Hy tar here her, & wrang here honde, And made reuful bere: 'Now þou wilt lef out of londe, Loky ich may after þe longe; Allas! þat ich ded nere! ¶ Allas my lef! what hast þou þo&yogh;t? In moche care ich am y-bro&yogh;t; Of me þou hast synne. After þat þou art a-gon, Op breyde me tyt of manyon, Of þyne riche kynne; A-wey my lef, þat ich was y-bore, ffor al my blisse is for-lore, And now wexeþ my pyne. ¶ Allone her-ynne ich wille wonye, And euere eft mannes mone shonye, Al for loue þyne.' 'Leman, al for þyne sake,— So doþ þe drake for here make, Whanne he is a-slawe,— Alle merthe ich wille forsake, And euere-more sorwe take, And shonye alle plawe.' ¶ He nam his gerdul on his hond, And his mantel þer-on he wond, And his ryng of golde. 'My leman, haue now þis to þe, And oþer whyle þenk on me, whanne ich ligge vnder molde; Gret wel fader & moder myn, By-lef her-ynne, & serue him With wel mylde mode. ¶ þulke lord ich þe by-teche, þat is of alle bale leche, þat deþ þolede on rode.' Out of þe borgh he wente anon, So swiþe so he my&yogh;te gon Ry&yogh;t to-ward þe stronde; Sone a schip he fond þare, þat was redy to fare In-to vncouþe londe. ¶ In-to þe schip anon he wente, And god wel sone such a wynd sente, þat to þe lond hem bro&yogh;te. þat schip was guod, þat water dep, And oþer whyle sore he wep, And was in moche þo&yogh;te; þo he in-to þe lond com, He solde his cloþes euerichon, And bo&yogh;te him pouere wede. ¶ Al his gold and al his fe, Among þe pouere delte he, þat hadde moche nede; Sone he it vnder-nom, þat he to one borgh com, þat moche was & kete. Sone so he þuder com, To þe temple he wente anon, God self to grete. ¶ Among þe pouere he wonede þare, In moche sorwe and moche care, ffor-to he fel to elde. Al þat he spelye my&yogh;te, Be daye and ek be ny&yogh;te; His pouere feren he delde. þo þe tydynge was y-come To þe fader of þe sone, How he was a-go, ¶ Him þo&yogh;te his herte wolde breke, O lepy word he ne my&yogh;te speke, ffor sorwe and for wo; Ofte he si&yogh;te & grente sore, To tar his shroud, his lokkes hore, þe guode olde man. &yogh;erne he gradde godis ore, þat he ne moste lyue namore; To swo&yogh;eny he be-gan. ¶ His moder with wel softe pas Wente to bedde, & gradde, 'allas, þat hy was y-bore.' Nolde hy neuere eft out-come, Ac þere hy wep for here sone, þat hy hadde for-lore. Alle þat þer-ynne were, Hem-selue drowe by þe here, And wronge hare honde. ¶ Be-so&yogh;te god þat sholde hem lere, To what londe þat he were, And where he were a-stonde. His fader & his moder bo, ffor hare sone were ful wo, þat ich ne may al telle. ffor to sechen hare sone, In what londe he were by-come, &yogh;onge men he sente snelle. ¶ It by-fel opon a day, þat &yogh;onge men nome hare way fforþ ri&yogh;t by þe cherche þere hare lord ny&yogh;t and day, Among þe pouere folk lay, Cristis wille to werche. He hem knew, and hy no&yogh;t him; Of hare guode hy &yogh;eue him, As it wolde falle. ¶ He herede god, and made him glad, þat he for his sone bad Almesse of þralle. Out of þe borgh hy wente sone To here lord til þat þe&yogh; come with wel guode spede. Tydynges none hy ne bro&yogh;te Of his sone, þat him so&yogh;te In vncouþe þede. ¶ þo þis &yogh;onge man y-woned hadde In toune as a pouere ladde, &yogh;eres seuentene, God self wolde his care wende, And to his fader him sende, And bringe him of tene. It by-fel in one ny&yogh;t þe mone shon swyþe bry&yogh;t, þe belward hym by-wende. ¶ þe leome of heuene he se&yogh; a li&yogh;t, And stonde ope godis kny&yogh;t, þat al þe cherche attende. Sone amorwe, so it was day, þat he by þis manne i-say, Wyde he it tolde. To þe cherche hy gonne teo, þe holy man for to seo, Boþe &yogh;onge and olde. ¶ þis holy man turnde his þo&yogh;t, Herynge of man ne kepte he no&yogh;t, þat frel is atte ende. Out of þe borgh he wente anon, To a water til þat he com, þer-ouer he moste wende. In-to þe schip he wente any&yogh;t, ffor elles-whar he hadde i-dy&yogh;t In-to vncouþe londe. ¶ He wende fare swiþe ri&yogh;t, Ac sone amorwe þo it was li&yogh;t, At Rome hy gonne a-stonde. þo he in-to þe lond com, In-to þe toune he moste gon, His lyflode to wynne. As he wente þorgh þe strete, His owene fader he gan mete, As he com fram his ynne. ¶ þo þe sone his fader mette, Wel myldeliche he him grette, And bad him of his guode. þe guode man grantede his bone, ffor al his blod gan menge sone Ope his owene fode. ffor &yogh;ut him spak þe holy man To his fader Eufemian, With wel mylde mode: ¶ 'þat guod þat þou þenkest do me, Iesu crist it &yogh;elde þe, þat deyde on þe rode. ffor &yogh;if it is in þyne mode, þat þou hauest eny fode, In vncouþe londe, Crist ich by-seche par charite, þat he wel to him by se, Wher þat he be a-stonde.' ¶ So sone so he spak of his sone, þe guode man, as was his wone, Gan to sike sore. His herte fel so cold so ston, þe teres felle to his ton, Ouer his berd hore. To his house þe pouere he bro&yogh;te; One &yogh;onge man him be-to&yogh;te To seruy him to queme. ¶ þere he wonede day and ny&yogh;t, And seruede god with al his my&yogh;t, &yogh;eres &yogh;ut seuentene. Some of þo þer-ynne were þe holy mannes clothes tere, þere hy le&yogh;e on his bedde. Ofte hy drowe him by þe here, And of water and of broþ him bere, And caste in his nebbe. ¶ Ofte hy him bete and burste, þat þe lord þer-of nuste, þo vnlede fode. þe&yogh; clepude him 'waste bred,' And weste þat he wer ded; I-wis hy wer wode. Al þe shame þat he dre&yogh;, þe whyle he wonede his fader ne&yogh;, He þolede with mylde mode. ¶ And ofte to god he gan grede, þat he for-&yogh;eue hem hare mysdede, And bro&yogh;te hem to guode. þe whyle he wonede in þe house, Eche day he se&yogh; his spouse, His fader & his moder. Ac sone he wente him to þe wowe, þat he neuere nere y-knowe Of hem ne of non oþer. ¶ þe holy man him þo&yogh;te þo þat his lyf was almest ydo, ffor siknesse þat he hadde. Parchemyn he him wan, And al his lyf wrot þer-an, As he lay in his bedde. ¶ Al he wrot opon his bok, How he his &yogh;onge wyf forsok, þo he of londe wolde. How he his mantel here by-tok, And his gerdel þat was so guod, And a ryng of golde. ¶ þat fel opon a soneday, þat alle men of cristis lay To þe cherche come, Clerkes, kny&yogh;tes, &yogh;onge & olde, þe emperour with his erles bolde, þe Pope self of Rome. ¶ þo hy þuder y-come were, To here al so hy sholde þere Hare seruise. Al so hy hare bedes bede, In þe luft hy herde grede, In a wonder wise: ¶ 'Comeþ alle now to me, þat synful haueþ for me y-be, And a-fongeþ &yogh;oure mede. Alle þat haueþ y-þoled pyne, Honger and þerst for loue myne, Ich &yogh;ow wille fede.' ¶ Of þis steuene hem þo&yogh;te wonder; ffele wende it were þonder; To gronde hy gonne falle. What þis cry be-tokny sholde, þat god hem sone schewy wolde, A-kneo hy beden alle. ¶ Alle þat þer-ynne were, I-herde &yogh;ut anoþer bere, Ri&yogh;t aboute none: 'Goþ, by-sechest godis kny&yogh;t, þat crist serueþ day and ny&yogh;t, þat he bidde for Rome.' þe Pope and his clerkes alle A-doun on kneo gonne falle, By-fore & ek be-hynde, ¶ And bede god almy&yogh;ty kyng, þat hem sende som toknyng Wher þorgh hy my&yogh;te him fynde. Iesu crist, þat is so mylde, Ruthe hadde of þis childe, þat was in care y-bounde. To hem he seyde, þe heuene spouse, 'Goþ to Eufemia[ne]s house, þere he worþ y-founde.' ¶ After þis steuene, op hy stode, And herede god with glade mode, Alle þat þer were. ffor no&yogh;t þe Pope was ful gram, Eufemian he vnder-nam, With wel sterne bere: 'O luþer man, why hastow y-hud þat he ne moste er be y-kud, þulke holy man?' ¶ þe emperour be-gan to chyde, And fele þat þer stode be-syde, To-ward Eufemian. ¶ Naþeles, with him hy &yogh;ede, þe Pope, and manye of hare dede To-ward þis house. þe Pope self and þe emperour, Hy so&yogh;te halle, hy so&yogh;te bour, So wel so hy couþe. ¶ Hy so&yogh;te him one stounde, Ac atte laste hy him founde, þer he lay in his bedde, þorgh an hyne of the house, þat moche of his lyf couþe, þat hem y-wissed hedde. ¶ By-fore þe bed hy stode þo, þe Pope and þe emperour al-so, Ac hy ne dorste hem tryne. Hy wende he were a lyues man, Ac his gost was out a-gon, I-bro&yogh;t he was of pyne. Eufemian a-doun bei&yogh;, His neb, his hondes, he vn-wrei&yogh;, With wel mochel drede. So swote breþ out of him tei&yogh;, þat alle þat wer þer nei&yogh;, þer-of wonder hauede. ¶ Out of his mouth stod a lem Bri&yogh;ter þan þe sonne-bem, þat al þe stede atende. A-doun hy felle, alle on kneo, To þonky god þat is so freo Of wonder þat hem sende. ¶ Op to-ward god held his honde; A writ be-twixe hy se&yogh;e y-folde, Hy þat wer þer-ynne. Eufemian a-doun bei&yogh;, þat writ he drou&yogh; & &yogh;erne tei&yogh;, Ne my&yogh;te he it wynne. ¶ þe Pope her-of was a-drad, In his herte, god he bad, þat him granty sholde þat writ þat was in his honde, þat he my&yogh;te it vnderstonde, Be-tokny what it wolde. ¶ þe Pope to þe dede bei&yogh;; þat writ out of his hond he tei&yogh;, Al with-oute gynne. þat writ anon he gan sprede, And by-fore hem alle rede, þat þo wer þerynne. ¶ þo sir Eufemian was y-war þat his sone lay þar, His armes he to-spradde, He tar his her, he tar his cloþ, And fel a-swo&yogh;e opon þe cors, So moche sorwe he hadde. ¶ By a stounde he gan op-stonde, To-tar his her & wrang his honde, þat alle folk mi&yogh;te rewe; He wep and made reuful cry; ffor him hy were wel sory, þat he him er ne knewe. ¶ "A-wey, lord, þat art vs a-boue, Why hele þou my leue sone? To longe in myn house, þat we ne moste him y-knowe, And for-&yogh;ute oure wowe, And kesse him with mouþe. ¶ A-wey, my sone, now listow here, And euere ich hopede of þe y-here, A-lyue þat þou were. Me þenkeþ my herte wil breke, Now þou ne mi&yogh;t with me speke, A-wey þat ded y-nere." ¶ þe drem in-to þe bour sprong, Of sorwe þat hem was among, þat in þe halle were. His moder lay þere wel sory, And axste what were al þat cry þat hy herde with ere. ¶ Of here sone me tolde anon, þat out whyle was a-gon, And how he was y-founde; And how he hadde þer-ynne y-woned, And al þis worldis blesse y-shoned, And þolede wel harde stounde. ¶ þo hy herde of here sone, How he was a&yogh;en y-come, Of here bedde hy sprong; Al hyre euel hy for-&yogh;at, And hardeliche a-doun stap, þe folk alle among: ¶ 'Remeþ me, for godis lone, And leteþ me go to my sone, I se myn owene fode.' þe teres felle to here kneo, þat al þat folk my&yogh;te wel y-seo, Hire brest al a-blode. ¶ So sone þo hy to him com, Ope þe lich hy fel anon, And keste it wel &yogh;erne; Hy keste his neb and his honde, Ope þe lich hy lay wel longe, Hire ne my&yogh;te noman werne; ¶ "A-wey, my sone, þou were my lyf! Sorwere nas y-neuere wyf, þan ich am for þe nouþe. ffor euere ich hopede þe to seo, Er ich deye, and speke with þeo, And kesse þe with mouþe. ¶ Ac al myn hope is y-lore, Now þou list ded me by-fore, And with me ne my&yogh;t speke. 'Lord crist, ich bidde þyn ore, Ne let þou me lyue namore, Ac let myn herte breke."' ¶ Hy wrang here hond, and si&yogh;te sore, To-tar here shroud, here lokkes hore, As hy were wod. 'Leue sone, by-seche ich þe, þou lete me deye now byfore þe, þe lyf me nis no&yogh;t guod.' ¶ Sone þer-after com his wyf, þat louede him more þan here lyf, In-to þulke house. So sone so hy com him to, Be-twixe here armes hy gan him fo, And keste him with mouþe; ¶ "A-wey! my lef, what hastow y-do? Why hastow þe y-heled so, In þyn owene house, þat þou ne woldest come me to, So frend o&yogh;te to oþer do, Ne ich þat was þy spouse? ¶ A-wey, þat ich was woman y-bore, Now ich haue þe for-lore, My leman so hende. Sorweful is me y-di&yogh;t, Now þou with me speke ne my&yogh;t, Ne reiche ich whyder to wende." ¶ Of hy stod by-fore hem alle, To-drou&yogh; here her, and here calle, As hy were vei&yogh;e. Bytere teres hy let falle, ffor hire were sory alle, þat here wepe y-sei&yogh;e. ¶ So moche sorwe þer was, Bote who-so hadde a tonge of bras, Ne my&yogh;te he it telle. þe day him was al-mest y-do, þe Pope and þe emperour al-so Ne my&yogh;te lenger dwelle. ¶ þat lich hy lete by-wake, and shrude With palle and with oþer prude, þat hy founde þere. With mochel li&yogh;t, and mochel song, þat holy cors hem alle among, Bischoppis to cherche bere. ¶ Amyddes ri&yogh;t þe he&yogh;e strete, So moche folk hy gonne mete, þat hy resten a stounde. Alle þe sike þat to him come, I-heled were swiþe sone, Of fet and ek of honde. ¶ þe blynde come to har si&yogh;t, þe crokede gonne sone ri&yogh;t, þe lame for to go; þat dombe were fenge speche, þe&yogh; herede god, þe soþe leche, And þat halwe al-so. ¶ þe day &yogh;ede, and drou&yogh; to-ny&yogh;t, No lenger dwelle hy ne my&yogh;t, To cherche hy moste wende; þe bellen hy gonne to rynge, þe clerkes he&yogh;e to synge, Euerich in his ende. ¶ þo þe cors to cherche com, Glad hy were euerichon, þat þer-ynne were. þe Pope and þe emperour, By-fore an auter of seint sauour, ¶ þer sette by þe bere. A-boute þe bere was moche li&yogh;t; With proude palle was be-di&yogh;t, I-beten al with golde. ffor to worschipe þis man, Al þat lond folk þuder cam, þat cors by-wake wolde. ¶ Alle þe sike þat þer were, As sone as hy touchede þe bere, Hol hy were anon Of þe euel þat hy hadde, &yogh;if hy in þe name badde Of þis holy man. ¶ To cherche come &yogh;onge & olde, þat holy cors to by-holde þat þuder was y-bro&yogh;t. A wel gentel marbel ston, To louke in his holy bon, Sone was by-so&yogh;t. ¶ þe þridde day was y-come, So it is þe londis wone, Me dude þe seruyse; þuder come more and lasse, þe Pope self song þe masse, With herte wel blyþe. ¶ þo þe masse was y-do, þe Pope and þe emperour al-so, þat holy cors hy kiste. Hy nome þe holy man, And leyde him in þe marbel ston, By-loke in one chiste. ¶ Alle þulke þat þer were, Herede god with loude bere, And cride him mercy, Of þe wondres þat he dude þo in þat ilke holy stude, ffor loue of allexi. ¶ By-seche we þanne, &yogh;erne & ofte, Crist self þat vs dere bo&yogh;te, þat his grace vs sende, þat we mote him seruy, And for þe loue of allexi, To his blesse wende. Amen.
